He reached back into the theater of old times, into the stone and mortar of medieval walls, into traditions that lay like dead things but weren't dead at all. The word gothic itself had wandered like a vagrant through time, marking peoples and places and ways of being until it came to rest here, in these pages, in these stories that some called crude and others called revelation.

The chivalry of old times runs through these tales like a dark river beneath the earth. In Otranto it flows strong and deep, carrying with it the ghosts of knights long dead, their honor and their steel both rusted but somehow still sharp. Walpole saw his world, saw the men in it who called themselves noble, and found them wanting. He looked back to times when honor meant something more than words spoken in parliamentary halls, when blood spilled meant something sacred.

And there was Frederic, written onto the page like a man carved from older stone. A prince who had known suffering, who had walked with death in foreign lands where infidels waited with sharp steel and sharper faith. The writers made him more than man, made him legend, excess piled upon excess until he stood like a mountain of chivalric virtue, terrible in his perfection.

They call it supply chain management and it moves like a river through the world. From raw earth to finished good, from order to delivery, all of it flowing through the hands of men who may never meet nor know each others names. Keith Oliver gave it that name in 1982 though the thing itself existed long before any man thought to name it. He wrote of planning and control and efficiency but these were just words for an older thing. A thing as old as trade itself.

Six pillars hold it up. Production. Supply. Inventory. Location. Transportation. Information. Each one a world unto itself, each one bearing the weight of commerce like ancient columns in some forgotten temple to trade.

Production stands first among them. Without it there is nothing. It begins with knowing what men want, though want itself is a strange and shifting thing. The market tells us, if we know how to listen. Like reading entrails or watching the flight of birds, men in offices parse numbers and charts seeking auguries of desire. Once known, these desires become orders. Orders become plans. Plans become schedules. Schedules become reality in factories chosen for their capacity to birth these wants into the world.

I saw this once at Walmart and again at Target. Every movement prescribed, every action written down in books thick as bibles. How to wear the uniform. How to unload the trucks. The whole dance choreographed down to the smallest step, because chaos costs money and time is the only thing you can't buy more of.

Then comes supply, the choices of what to make and what to buy. What to keep close and what to send away. Managers sit in rooms and decide which parts of the work belong to them and which belong to others. They call it outsourcing but really its just a way of making things move faster, like water finding the quickest path downhill. They call this velocity and chase it like men once chased gold, always seeking the perfect balance of quality and cost.

They came in the Victorian age these books and they were filled with things of the aristocracy and details heaped upon details until the words themselves groaned under their own weight. But there were two that walked a different path. Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights. Dark tales both of them carrying mystery like a shroud and bearing strangeness in their hearts that set them apart from their kin. This strangeness it gave life to their characters and showed the blackness in their souls and the reasons for what they done.

He walked in dreams Oliver did between Sikes and Crackit who quarreled like wolves over meat and their voices came to him through the darkness of his mind. Then gunfire split the night and screams rose up like birds scattered from a field and lights danced before him while unseen hands bore him away through the chaos. Through it all the pain stayed with him constant as hunger constant as death.

These dreams they came in both books like dark prophets bearing truth. In Oliver's tale they showed what lay inside him like a man gutted and laid bare showing all the hurt and knowing that filled him. When they shot him and he lived it again in chapter 28 he was powerless as a leaf in the wind. The dream showed how the control had gone out of him like blood from a wound. He could not even see who carried him away and the pain that first shocked him now just stayed with him quiet and terrible like a companion. You could see how the boy was broke down by then like Fagin wanted. Beat down so far he wouldnt even try to save his own life when the time came. The day it went and night came on and the silence stretched out forever while the hours ran like water through his fingers.

Years back I worked with the young ones after their schooling was done for the day. Small faces looking up from dogeared books and crumpled papers. Their struggles were many but reading and words were what I knew best. There was this boy. Adrian they called him. Third or fourth grade, memory fails. The letters on the page before him might as well have been hieroglyphs carved in ancient stone. Some sounds he knew true as sunrise, others escaped him like smoke in the wind. His English flowed pure as mountain water but his people came from south of the border, that much was certain.

We labored together in that fluorescent-lit room until the day his mother appeared. The other children had gone off somewhere, just a few stragglers remained when she walked in wearing worry like a shawl. No English passed her lips, just rapid-fire Spanish that I barely grasped with my meager learning. That's when the truth hit me like a hammer stroke: The boy could read well enough, just not in the tongue of his adopted land. Whether this knowledge served him after, I cannot say.

I tell this tale not for its own sake but to speak of the wall that stands between languages in our schools, particularly here in California where the border breathes like a living thing. Sometimes the barrier hides in plain sight. Even a child who speaks English pure as spring water might stumble reading it, like a man trying to cross a river on stones he cannot see. We all know this truth, but what's to be done? For Adrian the path was clear enough: teach him the strange shapes that make up English words. But for those who barely grasp our tongue, the answer splinters like light through crystal. No single solution will suffice. Two-language teaching, immersion, private instruction, special English classes - each alone stands weak as a sapling in strong wind. But together they might grow into something that holds.

The two-language way shows promise, not just for the Spanish-speaking children but for all. Studies tell us these children outpace their peers like wolves outrun sheep. Some fear this wastes what we have, but they're wrong as wrong can be. Make it the rule instead of the exception and watch them all flourish like desert flowers after rain. We don't need every teacher speaking two tongues - that's a fool's errand. But we can find helpers, guides who know both worlds, to bridge the gap between what is and what could be.

From youth we are told of something greater than ourselves. A vastness beyond knowing. Some find it in wooden pews and stained glass, others in ancient texts or deep within the hollows of their own hearts. Many take up the faiths of their fathers like old coats passed down, worn thin at the edges but familiar. Others cast off such inheritance entirely, prophets of their own small worlds where nothing exists beyond the reach of their understanding. We wander these paths like blind men feeling their way through darkness, seeking some light to lead us from shadow into day.

He said cardinal and nothing more. We set on the porch watching the rain beat against tin while smoke rose from our cigarettes like small ghosts in the wet air. Water rushed through the gutters and drowned the flowers that grew wild at the porch edge. His eyes fixed on some distant point where memory and rain met in the growing dark. The clothes hung from him now like empty flags, his hair thin as winter wheat. Neither of us spoke of what was coming. What words could stand against such truth. I moved closer and we watched the June rain fall in the twilight like tears from an indifferent god.

December took him five days after I turned twenty-two. The medicines they gave him bought time but not peace, extending his suffering like some cruel mathematical equation. I questioned what sort of god would author such torment. In the nighttime I spoke no prayers. If there was something out there listening it had turned from me long ago like a friend grown weary of my voice.

I could not watch the ending. Would not. The memory of his life meant more than witnessing its departure. I knew him better than the others, better than those who shared his blood, and knew he would not want his child to stand witness while death took its due. For three days I lay curled in darkness waiting for word.

None came.

He walked the fields of Caroline County like a man possessed by the soil itself, this Taylor, his mind ever fixed on the republic and what it might become. The earth spoke to him in ways that politics never could though he served in both worlds, the dust of legislation settling on his farmer's boots like so much chaff. His devotion to the land colored everything he touched, everything he thought, everything he feared might come to pass.

The republic stood naked before him, stripped of old world traditions that might have bound it like corpse wrappings. Here was virgin territory not just in soil but in governance and Taylor knew it. He saw how rights given by God or nature or whatever dark force ruled the universe were bound together like a hangman's knot, to fail together or hold fast as one. The government, he reasoned, must never touch these things.

In those days men spoke of natural states and Taylor knew what that meant. The strong would devour the weak and the clever would feast on both, same as it ever was. But civilization demanded better. Taylor held to his beliefs about good and evil like a man clutching a Bible in a thunderstorm, knowing that any government made by men must carry both seeds within it. Good principles protect what's yours, he said, they make the earth yield its bounty, they keep the moneylenders at bay. Self-interest drives all men but only becomes evil when it feeds upon others like a carrion crow.

The Constitution was his lodestone though he wanted it read pure and clean as spring water. No federal leviathan growing fat on taxes and power, nothing beyond what was writ plain on paper. But words alone were dangerous things, he knew, without the ghost of intention haunting their margins. For Taylor the Declaration was the true testament, the document that spoke of sovereign states standing apart yet together, like stalks of wheat in a field that bend together in the wind but keep their separate roots.

He stood there and looked down and the looking was a thing without meaning or purpose save that it was what he did. The mind worked at it like some machine grinding away at nothing, processing the scene before him without attachment or judgment or understanding. Thoughts came and went like dust devils in the desert, there and gone again before they could take hold.

Years back he'd bought him a book about drawing from the right side of the brain on account of some artist he knew told him to. Since he was no more than a boy he'd wanted to draw and this book laid it all out plain as day from what a pencil was to how the mind saw shapes in the world. It talked about framing things. How you could take the world and cut it down to size with invisible borders. How a kitchen full of things could become just a bowl of fruit floating in space if you knew how to look at it right.

Standing there now he couldnt frame nothing. The sight before him was too vast and terrible in its simple awfulness. Like them painters who went through their phases. Picasso with his blues and Monet with his gardens. If this was art then it was art of the basest kind. A masterwork in brown.

His fingers found the handle and his arm moved like it belonged to someone else. The water moved in its ancient circles, clear as crystal and just as cold. Little pieces broke away and vanished into that cold void but the main mass stayed put like some creature born to that porcelain bowl. He flushed again harder this time, desperate-like, but that brown testament to human waste just sat there mocking his efforts.

He stood there in his uniform, green tie cinched tight at his throat like a noose, holding that mop like it was some kind of talisman against what lay before him. Just another bathroom cleaner at the Rite Aid facing down what some nameless patron had left behind. After a spell he reached for the paper, wrapped his hand in it like them old mummies in Egypt till he couldn't see skin no more. Then slow and careful-like he reached down into them cold waters like reaching into the mouth of hell itself...

They die on the roads these children. Die in twisted metal and shattered glass while the night moves past like a dark river and carries their souls with it. The government men with their papers and statistics know why but knowing dont stop the dying. They say the brain aint ready. Say its too new and soft for such things as steel horses and velocity. Experience too is missing like some vital organ cut away leaving only an empty space where wisdom should dwell.

These young ones they drive together. Pack animals sharing metal coffins. The California men who study such things showed in their numbers how death follows youth like a dark companion. State men made laws. Papers that say when they can drive and who they can carry but laws are just words on paper and death pays no mind to such things.

Some say eighteen years aint enough. Zuckerman the head doctor says they seek the thrill like moths to flame caring nothing for the burning. Says we ought to wait till that fire dies down some. But we dont wait and they keep dying and soon there'll be more. Children of the boom times coming up behind ready to take their turn at the wheel.

The answer lies plain as bones in the desert. Keep them from the wheel till eighteen years have worked their tempering. Let the schools teach them still but keep them from the metal beasts that roam the highways. Let them learn slow and careful like. Six hours behind the wheel and fifty more with someone who knows the way of things. Make it the same in all places cause death dont care what state youre in when it comes calling.

This aint new thinking. Aint nothing that hasnt been thought before by men who've seen too many young ones wrapped in sheets by the roadside. But knowing and doing aint the same thing and we keep on like we always have watching them die in the dark.

They call it Central Auditory Processing Disorder but names dont matter much in the grand scheme of things. The brain takes what it hears and makes nothing of it. Like a broken radio receiver catching fragments of signals from somewhere far off and distant. The sufferers can hear alright. Their ears work just fine. But somewhere in the dark corridors of their mind the meaning gets lost. Gets twisted. Like smoke in the wind.

It wasnt always known by that name. Back in the old days round about 1950 they called it auditory imperception. Some Italian doctors, Bocca and his people, they started testing children who couldn't make sense of the sounds around them. Then Kimura came along with his theories about how the brain takes in sound from both sides. They had themselves a conference in 77. Started really looking into it.

The way it manifests is like a shadow across the mind. Some cant tell where a sound comes from, like they're lost in a dark room with voices all around. Others cant tell one sound from another or make sense of patterns in speech. Sarcasm flies right past them like a bullet in the night. Words get jumbled up, meanings lost. Its like their minds are trying to catch raindrops in a sieve.

To find it in a person they got to do tests. Audiologists and speech doctors watching how people listen, how they respond. Like tracking an invisible beast by the marks it leaves behind. They aint found no single way to catch it sure. No one knows where it comes from neither. They put people through their paces with words and numbers coming at them from all sides at once. Sometimes they stick machines in ears to measure the way the brain dances to sound. But still it remains elusive. Like trying to catch the wind in your hands.

They'd asked me what I aimed to do with my life and I told them plain. Said I meant to work with the children. The broken ones. The ones whose own blood had turned against them like vipers in the dark. Told them I'd walk into the Division of Family Services and take up that mantle. Not for glory. Not for coin. But because there are things in this world that need doing and someone needs doing them.

The values I carried weren't learned from no book. Service. Respect. The knowing of right from wrong that burns in a man's chest like hot coals. These weren't just words to me. They were like old bones buried deep in the earth. Fundamental. Ancient.

I remember the summer of '09, fresh from Piedmont College with psychology papers in hand, not knowing which way to point my feet. That's when I saw him. Just a boy. Sixteen summers old, sitting scared on my friend's couch like some wounded animal. His folks had done things. Bad things. Things that make God turn his face away.

I drove out to that house the next day after he called the law. Told the police what I knew, showed them my credentials like they meant something. They asked me to talk to the parents, said their hands were tied by the law. Those parents, they spoke in circles and shadows, calling their boy manipulative, trying to make simple what wasn't simple at all. That's when I knew. Knew what I had to become.

And justice. Lord, the justice. We talk about individuals like we honor them, but we're all trying to sand down our edges to fit in some box society built. I never did cotton to that. Walked my own path through school, wore what pleased me, colored my hair like wildfire, stuck metal through my flesh because it was mine to do with. Stood up with the GSBA folks, fought the old hatred wherever it showed its face. Because that's what justice is. Not some word in a book, but a thing you do with your hands and your heart and your voice.

Some folks say we're all just dust in the wind. Maybe so. But while we're here, we got work to do. Hard work. And I aim to do it.

Sleep comes like a thief in the night for some and not at all for others. The disorder they call insomnia stands before us like a dark specter, casting its shadow across both the biological and sociocultural realms of human suffering. They say it runs in the blood, passed down through generations like an old curse, while others claim it's born of the world we've built around us - the concrete canyons and electric lights that mock the natural order.

There are those who would categorize sleep's absence, sort it into neat little boxes with names like Dyssomnia and Parasomnia, as if giving the darkness a name might tame it. Primary disorders they call some, while others trail behind other afflictions of the mind like faithful dogs. The sleepless ones pace their nights away, while across town the oversleepers drift through days like ghosts, neither fully here nor gone. Then there are the sleepwalkers and the night screamers, their minds caught in some terrible dance between waking and sleeping.

Deep in the laboratories they keep their mice, watching them sleep and wake, studying the tiny sparks in their brains that decide between consciousness and oblivion. They found something called orexin in the hypothalamus, a messenger that speaks in the language of wake and sleep. The GABAB receptors stand guard like sentinels, and when they're triggered the sleep comes washing over like a dark tide. But if something's wrong with these sentinels, if they're broken or missing, then sleep becomes as elusive as smoke in the wind. They tested this with their chemicals and their mice, watching as the creatures surrendered to artificial sleep, and wrote down their findings in neat columns and graphs as if they'd captured some fundamental truth about the nature of consciousness itself.

Two and a half years I've walked these grounds. Four and a half seasons come and gone like wind across the valley. The eastern halls where they put me that first year stood at the far reaches of civilization, past which only the great concrete monuments to sport and spectacle rose against the grey Pennsylvania sky. From Stuart Hall to Willard was a pilgrimage of twenty-five minutes or more, longer still when the weather turned, as it often did in that place they called State College though it was neither state nor college but something else entirely.

An old graduate told me once how it used to be, the eastern dormitories separated from everything by vast tracts of nothing. Empty land that stretched like some forsaken prairie. Now steel and concrete rise where emptiness once dwelt. The Creamery. The infirmary. Apartment blocks that crowd the horizon like tombstones in some vast necropolis. The campus spreads like a living thing, consuming distance, making movement harder with each passing season. But there is salvation in the bicycle. Simple machine of chains and wheels, useless without riders, worthless without paths to ride.

My friend spoke to me of bicycles. He had forgotten them for years but remembered now like a man remembering his own hands. Bikes are great, he said, though fashion had turned against them for a time. They endured. A bowl of morning grain and the strength in your legs will carry you thirty miles or more. The mathematics of survival are simple. I live far now, as far as those eastern halls where once I dwelt, but the bicycle saves me. Thomas building lies twenty-five minutes distant by foot, but the bicycle devours that distance in five minutes or less if you're willing to push hard enough. Pollock Road cuts straight and true but it's treacherous, full of dangers seen and unseen, wheeled or walking.

Some speak of walking like it's salvation but I cannot spare the time. Without the bicycle there is only walking and walking takes what cannot be given. Forty minutes lost each day to Thomas building alone. Two hours and more each week vanished like smoke. Add the other wanderings, the appointments, the necessities. Time becomes a currency you cannot spend.

He watched as the world burned itself into submission through screens and steel and the false promises of men who wore suits like armor. Huxley had seen it coming. Had written of it in that book of his. Brave New World. A world where the individual was nothing and the mass of humanity everything and all of it controlled by strings pulled by hands unseen.

The people there lived like cattle. Bred for purpose. Each one conditioned from birth to seek pleasure like addicts seek their next fix. Above them the World Controller moved like some dark god. Puppet master of flesh and bone. Through the lens of Marx you could see the truth of it. The way the classes moved against each other like tectonic plates. Grinding. Crushing. Words like homogeny and reification scattered through the pages like broken glass.

The false consciousness lay heavy on them all. Like a blanket of fog that wouldn't lift. The common folk kept ignorant of their own chains. Delta. Gamma. Names for sheep who didn't know they were sheep. Their minds filled with hypnopædic whispers telling them to consume. To spend. To want. The Controller watching it all from his tower of ivory and steel.

No love existed in that world. No depth to any soul. Characters moved through the pages like ghosts. Hollow. Empty. The men spoke of women like they were meat. Pneumatic, they called them. The women no better. All of them rutting like animals without shame. Each class content in their ignorance. Happy slaves to a system that fed them lies with mechanical precision. Consume, it told them. Obey. Stay in line. And they did. God help them they did.

Four years back I sat in a room where they spoke of Islam, where men argued in circles about peace and violence like dogs chasing their own tails. The question hangs heavier now in the air than it did then, like smoke that won't clear. Since the towers fell I watched how the papers and screens shifted their tune from hatred to something like reverence, as if fear had transformed into a strange kind of worship. No one could have known then that a man named Obama, carrying the weight of Muslim blood in his veins, would stand for the highest office in this land.

The Prophet's story burns in my mind like a fever dream. The words they write of him stand against the truth like a house built on sand. They say he was gentle but history speaks otherwise, tells of tribes brought to heel under his sword, of conversions born not of choice but of steel and fire. Yet in these pages they paint him meek as a lamb, a misunderstood soul whom men sought like water in the desert.

There's something wrong in how they mirror the Christ's works. They tell of mutton and milk multiplied for forty men, as if copying from an older book, stealing glory from an older truth. It's a thievery of miracles, taking the bread of Christ's life and claiming it as their own. The writers craft their tales careful-like, building a false prophet from borrowed stones.

The stories come down through whispers, through men telling tales of other men telling tales, like smoke signals rising up through generations. Each telling makes the truth more distant, more suspect. They mean these chains of witnesses to strengthen their case but they only weaken it, like a rope frayed by too many hands.

What troubles me most is how they've fashioned this gentle prophet from the clay of lies. History tells us different - speaks of blood and conquest where they speak of peace. I wonder if those who bow toward Mecca know the true face of the man they follow, or if they too are lost in the maze of these carefully crafted stories.

The words of the Christ and what he held true in his days upon the earth were cast aside quick as a snake sheds its skin in the thinking that came after. Like tracks in the desert sand that fade with each passing wind we see the way of it moving further and further from where it began. The world now bears witness to something stirring in men's minds, a new way of seeing that cannot be unseen. There are those who cling to the old ways like a drowning man to driftwood but their numbers grow thin and their voices fade like dying embers in the night.

Among the believers there will come a knowing deep as roots in ancient ground. A hunger will rise in them to strip away the false words laid upon the truth like paint on stone, seeking what he who died upon the cross truly meant. Time will pass like water through fingers but what comes will come sure as darkness follows day. The great wheel will turn backward, grinding away the layers of man's invention like rust from old iron until naught remains but what the carpenter's son brought forth from God before others spoke their piece.

When this tide washes over the lands of the new world and the old, drawing souls in its wake like flotsam in a river, the church will stand. But as the hands of time spin widdershins the many voices that now cry out in His name will fade to one. Where now stand walls between believers they will crumble like adobe in the rain, leaving only the bare earth where once stood monuments to difference.

The world has seen such turnings before. Rome that once fed Christians to lions knelt before the cross. This land that once bound men in chains now sees them rise to power. So too will come this great undoing in matters of faith, this stripping away of all that was built upon His words until only truth remains. They will learn to read His words like one reads the sky for coming storms, seeking meaning beneath the surface of things.

In the before time there was only the faith of Abraham, the wellspring from which all else flowed. One God, one truth handed down from heaven, and the ancient words writ in blood and fire. When Rome's legions marched into Jerusalem they found a people already split like a lightning-struck tree - Sadducees, Pharisees, Essenes, Zealots, and the common folk who knew only toil and prayer.

The Jungle speaks truth of man's nature, raw and unvarnished like a blade left to rust in the rain. Deep in their cores men harbor greed and selfishness that cant be washed clean. They look only to their own betterment and care nothing for those beneath them scrabbling in the dirt. You see it clear as bone in the factory owners and their kind, those who lord over the great mechanical beasts of industry.

These men, they build their empires on flesh and bone and blood. Their factories rise like iron mountains against the sky, and Sinclair writes of them saying how "The line of buildings stood clear-cut and black against the sky; here and there out of the mass rose the great chimneys, with the river of smoke streaming away to the end of the world." That smoke carries death in it. The owners know this truth but care nothing for it. They watch their chimneys vomit black poison into God's air and let their sewage run thick with animal waste and worse things, things that have no name.

The workers are no more than cattle to them. Less than cattle maybe. "From top to bottom the place is simply a seething cauldron of jealousies and hatreds," Sinclair says, "there is no loyalty or decency anywhere about it, there is no place in it where a man counted for anything against a dollar." Men work until their hands bleed and their backs break and then they're cast aside like spent shells. No warning. No mercy. The law dont protect them and never did.

They lived in Packingtown like prisoners in hell, breathing poison and drinking death. No help would come. The unions that sprouted up were carrion birds feeding on desperate men. These people, these workers, they were slaves in all but name. Sinclair saw it true when he wrote how they were "hanging always on the verge of starvation and dependent for its opportunities of life upon the whim of men every bit as brutal and unscrupulous as the old-time slave drivers." That was the truth of it. Raw and cruel as winter.

In the dark chambers of Poe's mind there lived a poem called Dream-land and he called it among his better works though who can say what constitutes better in the realms of madness and despair. Within its verses he spoke of Thulé, that ancient place, and Mabbott who came after traced it back to Virgil like a man tracking wounded prey across timeworn earth. Virgil knew it as some far northern isle beyond Britain where Greek minds dared not venture, but there was another source closer to Poe's time, for he had developed a powerful hunger for German writers and their words lay heavy in his thoughts.

The connection runs deep as blood. Karl J. Arndt wrote of it in his testament to literary kinship, speaking of how Poe's words echoed Goethe's like twin bells in a forgotten tower. Goethe himself stood as a titan among men, creator of Faust, that dark drama born in two parts like some bifurcated beast, first in 1808 and again in 1832 when death came calling for its author.

Hidden in Faust's second coming was "The King of Thulé," a tale of a dying queen and her gift of a goblet to her king. The king, mad with grief and drink, watched his world darken until he too sought death's embrace, casting the goblet into black waters before closing his eyes forever. Here lay the shadow of Poe's own demons, his drinking and his losses mirrored in this German king's despair.

They were companion pieces though separated by language and ocean, these tales of Thulé. In Dream-land Poe painted landscapes of darkness where ghosts of dead friends wandered like lost cattle on a moonless plain, a world drained of color and hope. It was as if he had walked into Goethe's grief-stricken realm and found it suited him, found it matched the darkness in his own soul.

Goethe's words would have reached Poe through various channels, not least through Tennyson whom Poe regarded with reverence approaching worship. The German's influence spread like wildfire through the literary world of that time, and Poe, ever the watchful crow, would have seen and known and understood.

The law speaks of malice and rights and consequences but the truth of it lay deeper than that, in the dark recesses of a man's soul where duty and indifference wage their ancient war. In California where the sun beats merciless upon concrete and steel they wrote these words into books of law, these words about punitive damages and what makes a man culpable for the suffering of others.

The woman Palmer had walked the aisles of D&D Markets that October evening like any other soul seeking sustenance in the fluorescent temple of commerce. The applesauce lay spilled and glistening on the floor like some visceral warning ignored. Wayne had seen it first, told Martin who sat in his office eating his dinner like a king in his castle. Fifteen minutes passed and Haddigan came too with the same words of warning. Martin dismissed them both with the casual cruelty of a man who had forgotten what it meant to care for the safety of others.

The clock marked half past five when Palmer's feet went out from under her and she lay broken on the cold tile floor, her back twisted by gravity and neglect. Before her there had been others, five souls who had fallen in that same year, their accidents recorded in ledgers that spoke of liability and loss.

The question before the judge was one of malice, that dark flower that blooms in the heart of men. The law speaks of oppression and fraud but what transpired in that store was something older. Martin had known of the danger, had been told twice of the threat that lay waiting. He had known of the five who fell before, yet he chose to sit and eat while danger lurked in his domain. The law calls this conscious disregard, this willful turning away from the probability of harm.

In the end the judge would have to weigh these things: the repeated warnings ignored, the history of falls that came before, the casual dismissal of duty that spoke of something deeper than mere negligence. The law provides for punishment when malice can be shown, when a man knows the consequences of his inaction and chooses still to let others suffer. And in this case the evidence lay clear as blood on sand.

The wanting lived in her like a starved thing. It came upon her at fourteen summers and stayed, a dark passenger riding the hollow spaces between heartbeats. Three years gone and still it lingered. Not a thing but a someone, she reckoned, though no boy had stirred that deep well within. They came and went like autumn leaves, their awkward advances scattered by winds they could not name. She pondered this strangeness in the dark hours, this emptiness that defied the natural order of young girls. Years of thinking brought nothing but shadows of answers, yet still she carried on, the question burning like a coal in her chest.

The house stood quiet most days. Her folks were peaceful people who walked soft in the world. They lived without the thunder of argument save for when their daughter's wild spirit pulled against the reins of their quiet ways. She was their opposite star, burning bright and wild where they glowed steady, yet carrying their kindness like an inheritance.

But this day the peace broke. Moving room to room seeking something unnamed, she heard her mother's cry cut the air like a blade. Kitchen-ways, where the sound died quick as it was born. She ran, heart hammering against her ribs. Mama lay twisted on the tile, pain writing itself across her face in cursive lines. Words came broken and scattered between breaths. Hospital, she said. The girl's hands found purchase, muscles remembering the strength learned in other seasons. She lifted her mother like a child might lift a wounded bird, gentle despite the urgency burning in her blood.

The hospital air carried its own scripture of antiseptic and suffering, though she paid it no mind. Her world had narrowed to the weight in her arms, the need to find help. She called out and white-clad figures appeared like ghosts, wheeling out a stretcher that swallowed her mother into the fluorescent depths of those sterile halls. Left alone, she sat with worry gnawing at her bones.

All this because of a vase too high, a stepping stool too treacherous. The highest cabinet had won its silent war with gravity, and her mother had paid the price.

They sought truth in numbers and blood. The Mediterranean way of eating, ancient as the olive groves themselves, promised less death from the heart's betrayals and the brain's dark hemorrhages. They called it aMed, this scoring of sustenance, marking the consumption of what grows from earth and tree, the fish that swim in waters both warm and cold, the pressing of olives for their oil. They shunned the flesh of beasts and the white fat that runs like tallow.

The knowledge wasn't new. Others before had tracked the dying, counted the fallen to the old ways versus the new. They found fewer corpses among those who ate as their ancestors did along those ancient shores. The fat ones, given choice between this old way and the modern lean, shed their burden better when they followed the path of olive and grape.

They watched the nurses, seventy-four thousand and more, women who tended the sick and dying across eleven states of this American empire. For twenty years they watched them, marking their eating six times over, through papers filled with boxes and numbers, validating their truth through hospital records and death certificates. They tracked the heart's failings and the brain's betrayals, confirmed in sterile rooms or on cold metal tables. Some they called probable, these casualties of modern life, when papers couldn't be found but the death was certain all the same.

They measured everything. Weight and smoke and pills, the monthly blood of women and the medicines they took when it ceased, the running and walking and moving through time. They built models of numbers, trying to separate truth from coincidence, adjusting for the chaos of human existence.

In the end, the numbers spoke clear as bones. Twenty years of watching showed two thousand heart failures, seventeen hundred strokes, a thousand dead from hearts and brains combined. Those who followed the old ways, who scored highest in their adherence to olive and fish and grain, they died less. The numbers said it plain - their risk was less by nearly a third compared to those who ate the modern way.

The truth was there in the counting of the dead.

Hitler lives, the sign read. Just that and nothing more.

The girl stood alone at the corner holding cardboard above her head like some prophet of old, the black letters stark against the pale surface. Burma they called it now though some remembered Myanmar, that place of green jungle and red earth where men in uniform had taken what wasnt theirs to take. They had come in the night in 1962 with their rifles and their papers and their proclamations and when morning came the old way was gone.

The monks came first. Orange robed and barefoot they walked the streets in their thousands, silent in their protest like burning autumn leaves caught in a windless day. Saffron Revolution, the papers called it. As if revolution could be named like a child or a beloved pet. The people watched and then they too came forth but the men in uniform had waited long enough. They came with their guns and their boots and their ancient rage. They broke down monastery doors and dragged the monks into the street. Foreign men with cameras disappeared into cells never to return. One day they shot a Japanese man named Kenji Nagai dead in the street for nothing more than holding a camera. The official count said thirteen dead but a colonel who fled told different tales. Several thousand, he said. Several thousand souls.

This was an old story told new. Since men first gathered in tribes there were those who would rule by fear and blood. Roman emperors who claimed divine right. Japanese kings who called themselves gods. Even now in America men in suits spoke to other men in suits about power and control and the divine right of presidents.

The stories piled up like cordwood. Tiananmen Square where students fell by hundreds or thousands depending on who told the tale. Rwanda where Hutu killed Tutsi until the streets ran red. Hitler and his Third Reich building death into an industry. The world turned and turned and nothing changed except the names of the dead.

The legacy of Duke they called Ellington lived in the long years of his craft and in how he shaped the men who played for him like a sculptor shapes clay. His fingers on ivory keys whispered soft and low through the pieces we speak of here but it was in the writing of the music that his true power lay dormant and waiting. He built frameworks of sound like a carpenter builds the bones of a house, letting the soloists wander through the rooms he created, their instruments crying out in the night like lost souls seeking redemption. The framework held them but did not bind them and in this way the music lived and breathed like something wild yet contained.

He knew each man's sound like a father knows his son's voice. Knew how the brass would weep and how the reeds would sing and how they would all come together in the dark of the night when the music called them home. In this knowing he wrote pieces that would echo through time like footsteps in an empty hall.

The scholars speak of Creole Love Call as if speaking of holy scripture, telling how he made the human voice into something that was both more and less than human. The piece moves slow like molasses in winter, twelve bars stretching out across six choruses like six days of creation. First comes the voice and reeds speaking to each other like lovers in the dark, then the trumpet crying out muted and blue as midnight. The clarinet soars high above while the piano whispers secrets underneath. The band rises up like a congregation in prayer, brass and reed calling back and forth across the divide. In the fifth chorus everything comes together like judgment day, reeds calling high and brass answering with thunder. Then back to the beginning, voice and reed once more, but now the voice growls like something caught between heaven and hell.

In Hot and Bothered recorded when the calendar turned again, Miley's trumpet speaks in tongues while Baby Cox's voice answers in sounds that might have been words in some forgotten language. It Don't Mean a Thing brings Nanton's trombone moaning low and sweet like a lost soul finally finding its way home. All of it bearing Ellington's mark like cattle branded on the range, each piece carrying his signature written in notes instead of ink.

The shells speak their own truth and man has long sought to understand their language. They spiral in the darkness of time like ancient scrolls waiting to be read. In 1917 Thompson wrote that we had not yet begun to dream in numbers when looking at living things and his words echo still through the halls of science like a ghost that won't rest.

The mathematics of life and death reside in these calcium tombs we call shells. They wind their way through space like cosmic dancers following rules we barely comprehend. We took the genus Prunum, those small white prophets of the sea, and laid them bare under the X-ray's merciless eye. The machine called CerioShell consumed our numbers and spat forth possibilities - shapes that could be, shapes that never were, shapes that might yet come to pass in the slow grinding of evolution's wheel.

The shell is nothing more than a tomb that grows. It spirals through time and space like a creature possessed, marking its passage in degrees, each revolution a testament to its existence. These turns we call whorls, spinning around an axis invisible as God. The columella stands as a pillar of calcium, bearing witness to the creature's passage through time. Each whorl speaks to its neighbor across a line we name suture, though it sutures nothing. The final whorl carries the living flesh within its curved walls, while above it the spire reaches toward heaven like a cathedral's tower.

They can be viewed from all angles - apex to base, face-on or turned away - but their truth remains encrypted in calcium and time. To count their whorls is to count their days, marking each quarter turn like the phases of some molluscan moon. The aperture traces its path through space like a soul leaving its mark on the world, each moment captured in coordinates of flesh and shell.

These are the mathematics of life itself, numbers that dance on the edge of comprehension. By understanding their dance we might glimpse the face of evolution itself, though it turns away from our gaze like a shy child. The shells wait, patient as stone, for us to learn their language.

The dead children of Indonesia lay quiet in their graves these past ten years, their numbers unchanging like ancient stones in a barren field. The nation moved forward in some ways, yes, bringing water where there was none and cleaning filth where it festered, but the children and their mothers kept dying all the same, their blood seeping into earth that cared nothing for millennium goals or government promises.

They had their midwives now, seven out of ten births blessed with hands that knew something of bringing life into the world. But these women, these traditional healers with their ancient knowledge, they stood helpless when the real darkness came, when the blood flowed like river water and death stalked the birthing rooms. The numbers told a story but it was a story written in half-truths and shadows.

In the cities they cut the babies from their mothers' wombs when they must, clean knives and sterile rooms, but in the villages they did not. Could not. The difference between urban and rural was the difference between life and death, seven percent versus two, numbers that meant everything and nothing at all. And the poor, they suffered worst of all, as they always had and always would, twenty-seven percent less likely to see a doctor's face or feel a healer's touch.

The question that remained was as old as suffering itself: how to stop the dying. Some said to build programs, targeted and precise like a rifleman's bullet. These programs would show results quick and clean, numbers to please the men who counted such things. But there was a darkness in this path too. When money flowed to one place it dried up in another, like a river changing course, leaving death in its wake. And the paperwork, endless as desert sand, forms upon forms upon forms, a tower of babel built of bureaucracy while mothers bled and babies died in the dark.

The music they called Popular had grown wild and uncontrollable like some dark vine stretching across a century of human experience, its tendrils reaching into places where no classification could follow. Within its twisted branches lay the subspecies, bastard children of rap and rock and country and jazz and folk, each spawning their own mutant offspring until the vine became a forest unto itself.

Among these dark woods stood Heavy Metal like some ancient and terrible god, its presence felt these forty years past. It spoke in tongues of rage and despair and sometimes in whispers of things men ought not speak of. The people who found this god began to shape it, to carve from its flesh new idols, each more terrible than the last, until the very meaning of the thing became lost in its own shadow.

Now the metal stands fractured like a broken mirror, each shard reflecting something different yet the same. To understand this thing you must go back to where it began, to the movement itself, for it was never just music but something older, something that lived in the blood.

Metal was born in darkness and nursed on violence. More, always more. More thunder in the bass, more screaming in the night, more blood on the altar. The players were priests of their craft, their fingers dancing across strings like witch doctors working ancient magicks. In those days the drugs came like a flood, mid-seventies, turning men's minds to vapor and their music to something from beyond the veil. They made records that spoke in tongues, hiding behind chemical ghosts and electrical storms. The darkness they brought forth was new and terrible and true, not like the sugared lies that filled the airwaves. They reached back through time to the Romantic dead and pulled forth something primal, something that had always waited there in man's heart.

In the years before the dreamers came with their twisted visions and their warped canvases there was another who walked alone. Henri Rousseau. He crafted dreams both sleeping and waking and laid them bare on canvas like prophets of old inscribing visions on stone. The Dream he called it, this thing of 1910, this testimony to wonder and terror both. In it a woman lies pale and naked on a velvet couch while dark jungle things watch her from the shadows with eyes like burning coals. The painting spoke to more than just the scene it showed. It spoke to Rousseau's own hunger, his desperate wanting. Recognition. Acceptance. The validation of men who dealt in paint and canvas like priests dealing in salvation.

He was born in Laval in the year 1844 when the world was younger and simpler and his father worked metal and sold hardware and lived as the middle folk lived. The boy learned no art save what his own hands taught him and for forty years he collected tolls like some ancient ferryman of souls, though they called him douanier, a title that wasnt his to claim. His first wife Clémence died and before her eight babies that never drew breath proper and in the end there was only Julia left to him. Grief sat heavy on him like a crown of thorns and he turned to painting like a drunk turns to whiskey, seeking something to fill the void that death had carved in him.

He painted in the time of giants. While Matisse and his kind sought to break the old ways like mirrors in which they saw reflections they could not abide, Rousseau wanted only to join their ranks. To be counted among them. He who had no learning and no credentials save what the years had given him. Gordon wrote that Matisse feared convention like it was a poison in his veins while Rousseau chased it like a man dying of thirst chases a mirage in the desert. The truth of it was written in every brushstroke, every color laid down by hands that had come too late to art but would not be denied their chance to speak.

The old ones spoke of truth and beauty like twins born of the same darkness, bound in blood and breath. Keats knew it. Wrote it on paper that yellowed and crumbled but the words stayed true as bone. Beauty is truth, truth beauty. Nothing more to know in this world or the next.

We learn what we learn. Through books and through pain and through the long dark nights of experience. But the knowing of right and wrong, of what shimmers with grace and what falls dead and cold - that comes from somewhere deeper. Some cavern in the soul that no light ever touched. We try to speak of it, to capture it in words like butterflies in a killing jar, but it escapes. Always it escapes.

Take the Mona Lisa. Men speak of shadow and light, of technique and history, but these words are just wind. They dont touch the heart of it. Ask a man why he loves a painting or a story and watch him struggle like a wounded animal. Theres just something about it, he'll say, and in those words lies more truth than in all the critics' tomes.

O'Connor knew. You tell a story because nothing else will do. Because some truths cant be spoken plain. They need the cover of fiction like a man needs shelter in a storm. The same with right and wrong. Wittgenstein saw it too. Ethics cant be caught in the net of language. It lives in that space between words where meaning drowns.

The connection runs deep as marrow. Art and morality touch us in places we cant name, like ghosts passing through walls. Literature carries this burden heaviest of all. McKean said it true - you cant separate the story from the moral any more than you can separate the blood from the vein. Values run through words like rivers through a landscape, carving deeper channels with each passing year. This is why we read. This is why we write. To touch that nameless thing that lives in the spaces between what we can say and what we know to be true.

The Germany that stands now rises like some ancient colossus, a thing unified and terrible in its strength, its culture bleeding through the veins of earth from the shadowed peaks of München down to where Kiel meets the cold Baltic waters. This same blood runs west to east, from where Köln squats by the Rhine through the heartland to Dresden's stone shoulders against the Elbe. That such a beast should spring from many heads surprises none who know its past.

Germania. The old ground. The name itself carries wars in its syllables, disputed by men who make their trade in dead words and older bones. Tacitus, that Roman who wrote of northern shadows, claimed it came from the Tungrians, those who crossed the Rhine and fought the Gauls until their original name - Germans - stuck like dried blood to history's pages. Caesar, that first namer of things beyond Rome's reach, took the word Germanus from Gaulish tongues and used it to mark those he had broken from those he had not. Some say it meant neighbor in that old speech, though others trace it to the ger, that spear they carried into battle, or to garim, that Irish word for shouting, as if the Germans were nothing but noise and fury given flesh.

Tacitus wrote in his ninety-eighth year after their Christ that these people must have sprung from the earth itself, pure and unmixed, for what man would cross seas to reach such a place of wild darkness and bitter skies unless he had been born to it. The land itself rejected strangers.

And the Romans, those builders of empires, they came and went like summer storms, taking what they could carry and sometimes leaving their dead. The Germanic tribes appeared like wolves at the empire's edges, trading what they took from the land and sometimes their own blood, serving in legions not their own. They were becoming what they would be, though they did not know it then.

The play speaks of masks and shadows, of the way men and women wrap themselves in false skins like snakes shedding what God gave them. And in the end they must cast off these skins or be lost to them forever, their souls drifting like smoke in the dark spaces between what is and what seems to be. But the casting off brings its own darkness. Some will turn away. Some will bare their teeth. Some will forgive and some will not and in the end each must choose between the truth of self and the bonds that tie them to the world of men.

When woman becomes man the question comes unbidden like a thief in the night. Why. Why does she turn from what the Lord made her to be. Viola speaks of preservation, of survival in a world gone wrong. The captain who helped her speaks gentle words but the world does not. I'll bring you to a captain in this town where lie my maiden weeds, she says, as if those clothes could shield her from the wolves that walk on two legs.

She walks as a man among men but the price is isolation, cut off from the sisterhood that might have sheltered her. And the deception breeds more deception like maggots in summer meat. Olivia sees in her what she wishes to see. Whither my lord, Cesario husband stay, she cries out, while Orsino speaks words that carry weight like stones: Boy thou hast said to me a thousand times thou never shouldst love woman like to me.

The modern eye might see something else entirely in this masquerade of flesh and bone. Might see how the lies peel back layers of truth like skin from an orange. Olivia and Orsino both carry secrets in their hearts dark as river bottom mud. When Olivia looks upon Cesario does she see man or woman or something that dwells in the spaces between. But Shakespeare cares not for such modern thoughts. His Olivia is a mirror held up to those who judge by flesh alone, who see only what their eyes tell them to see.

At the last she turns from Cesario to Sebastian as easy as wind changes direction. A sister you are she, she says, and blood ties replace what was never love but only its shadow.

They spoke of the German rule in those lands as something brutal and dark, a thing of nightmares that left the Ovaherero and Nama dead in its wake. But empires aint simple things and this one stretched across worlds unknown, each territory carrying its own weight of history like a stone. In the east they found Africans who could read and write when the British came in 1919, taking what the Germans had built. In Kamerun too the natives had learned their letters and numbers, or so they said in those days.

But South West Africa was different. A place where the wind carried death across the desert and the missionaries did what the government would not. They taught the natives while the state turned its back, saving its coins and care for the white children who sat in proper schools with proper teachers. The missionaries got what scraps fell from the government's table and nothing more. This was how it went and how it would go, marking the land long after the Germans were gone. While other colonies raised up educated men, South West Africa's people remained in darkness, untouched by learning's light.

The old books tell it, most in German, written when the empire still breathed. They wrote of schools and systems, of how things were done in those days. Later came the English writers who picked through the bones of the dead empire, comparing one colony to another like a man comparing cattle at market. Cohen wrote of it too, said the whites who settled there made it what it was, different from the east where fewer Europeans made their homes.

The land itself was neither kind nor cruel, temperate they called it though the desert stretched endless and bare. By 1913 fifteen thousand whites had come to stay, more than anywhere else in the German territories. In East Africa there were only five thousand or so. The numbers told their own story, but numbers aint always truth.

They rode forth across that disputed ground, these two nations, like ancient enemies circling one another in the dust and heat of fifty-seven years. From eighteen thirty-six to eighteen ninety-three they clashed and bled, the high water mark coming in forty-six when American forces descended like biblical locusts upon Mexican soil, claiming Texas and the Southwest territories in a tide of manifest destiny that knew no bounds.

The border between them was a wound that would not heal. Like all nations sharing such scars upon the earth they fought over God and custom and the old ways of their fathers, though perhaps they knew not why. Their hatred was a thing passed down from the English and Spanish crowns, ancient as the stones themselves, deep as the waters that divided their lands.

Seventeen times did these nations clash proper in those years, though countless smaller skirmishes dotted the borderlands like stars in the night sky. Bandits and mercenaries crossed back and forth across that imaginary line drawn in blood, raiders striking at settlements while good men slept. The frontier was a lawless thing then, untamed and wild as the hearts of the men who sought to claim it.

The old Catholic ways of Mexico stood in stark opposition to the Protestant fervor of the Americans, much as fascism and communism would divide nations in the century to come. But all things must end. As the century waned like a dying fire, Mexico found itself bound to American interests not by conquest but by coin. The hunger for land gave way to the hunger for profit, and the old blood feuds faded like tracks in the desert sand, though the memories remained, etched deep in the bones of both peoples.

Fifteen years back the sickness came. Not gradual like most afflictions but sudden and complete, a thief in the night stealing what was mine to keep. I hadn't known such illness existed in the world.

I was a nurse then. Chose it from some deep hollow need for safety, the kind that never came in childhood. They'd say it like gospel: People gonna stay sick, always need tending to. So I buried my dreams of science and words and took up the white uniform like a shield against what might come.

Then there I was. Forty-six years walked on this earth, alone, pockets empty as a church on Monday, body betraying everything I'd built. Still am that way. After fifteen years living off government mercy ain't nothing left to call mine except breath and bone. Each sunrise brings its own war against security, dignity, whatever scraps of pride remain. Nothing certain no more except one truth hard as stone: Wouldn't have survived without blood kin and them few friends stood fast. When the darkness comes it strips you bare of any notion of strength.

Life's got its ambush points. No deed to safety exists in this world no matter how careful you lay your plans. Some storms too big for one soul to weather alone.

This country needs weaning off the government teat, true enough. That basket's rotted clean through. But better we learn to trust each other again than dig our separate holes in the ground waiting for judgment.

They talk about rugged individuals built this land. Truth is it was built on shared bread and borrowed tools. Them pioneer wagons didn't cross them mountains alone. Was communities moving west together, sharing what they had.

Keep your preparations. Got my own kit - medical supplies, water tablets, window plastic and tape against whatever poison might come floating down. Flashlights and batteries lined up like soldiers. Candles and matches sealed against damp. Canned goods stacked in rows. You got land, plant it. Got wood, burn it.

But while you're fixing to survive, know your neighbor's name. Might be the hand that pulls you through.

In the old world there was a prince. Born to wealth and station in a time before Christ walked the earth. He who would become the Buddha. The prince walked away from all he knew and found enlightenment beneath a tree and from his teachings came the thing men would call Buddhism and within it the orthodox strain known as Theravada. Twenty five hundred years gone now and the religion aint what it was. You can see it in Sri Lanka where they cut the waters in ceremony each year, monks and common folk alike gathered for some ritual the Buddha never spoke of nor ordained. The changes run deep as bone. From the surface down into the marrow of salvation itself. The keepers of the faith both robed and common have worked changes in their doctrine like a smith works iron, bending to forces within and without, some meaning harm and others meaning nothing at all.

Words have weight here and must be measured careful. There are forces inside and forces outside. Inside being them that follow the Buddhasasana whether they wear the robe or no. Outside being all others who dont. Some forces come with malice burning in their hearts like coal and seek to tear down what Buddha built. Others pass by like wind neither helping nor harming though their passing may leave marks all the same. These words will echo through what follows like footfalls in an empty hall.

You got to know what lies at the heart. The three jewels they call the triple gem: Buddha, Dhamma, Sangha. The Dhamma itself held in three baskets of ancient text. The Suttas which tell the tales, the Vinaya which sets the rules, and the Abhidhamma which speaks of things beyond the world we know. They talk of Anatta which means the soul aint real, and Dukkha which means life is suffering, and Anicca which means nothing lasts. A man must know these things deep in his gut if he aims to break free from Sansara, that wheel of death and birth that turns and turns without end. When the wheel stops turning then desire and hatred and confusion stop too. The Vinaya tells men how to live. Common folk got five rules: dont kill, dont lie, dont steal, dont rut like animals, dont poison yourself with drink or drugs. Monks got more rules than stars in the sky. But at the center of it all like the hub of some great wheel are the four noble truths. First that life is pain. Second that wanting causes pain. Third that pain can end.

original_texts:
Culture plays a significant role in any negotiation. Culture can be defined as much by what it is not as what it actually is and what it signifies. Culture is not homogenous, nor is it a specific thing. It is also not singular or uniform. Statements such as “all Russians are stubborn” or “all Japanese are accommodating,” are inherently broad and overly simplistic. While the understanding of a culture’s generalizations are appropriate, it is much more productive to a negotiator to understand the significance of a culture to the matter at hand, and how that culture’s attitude can and will affect the table talks. When one approaches a foreign culture, one experiences it in a way that is relatable to his own culture, and comparisons necessarily arise. 

Attempting to understand a foreign culture or mindset can involve anything from studying its history to realizing its prejudices. Rather than judging or attempting to change a culture, one must simply accept it for what it is, and work within its boundaries, especially within the scope of negotiation, and most especially if one comes to the table with a weaker bargaining position. Likewise, if a negotiator finds himself on “away” territory, a respect for traditions and beliefs can only help in getting over any cultural barriers and move the negotiation forward.

It is important to note that culture does not necessarily limit itself to a national/international dichotomy. Most companies within a given nation establish their own corporate culture. For instance, a corporate culture might emphasize long hours in the office or a more relaxed schedule. Evidence of a corporate culture can be seen in employee dress codes, in communication style (direct v. indirect communication, delegation of duties), and hiring practices. Some companies encourage philanthropy at any level from employees, others restrict it to “company approved” charities or fundraisers. One need only look at the differences in American corporate culture from company to company (and indeed, intra-company diversity exists even from region to region, urban to suburban environments included) to appreciate the diversity of thought that can reside within a particular societal culture. Certain cultures are not nearly as stratified as American culture, and may appear more uniform to an outsider, but a similar exterior is simply a sign to dig deeper. 

Values are even more important to understand, because they provide the why of a culture. If saving face or communal harmony are valued within a culture, it is certain that a negotiator will not publicly shame his company or his superior in order to succeed at the negotiation table. Likewise, a negotiator from a culture which gives greater weight to a hard-driven bargain will not necessarily be driven to settle at the earliest opportunity. Taking these generalities into consideration is important before one gets to the negotiating table. However, a negotiator is well-served to learn something about his opponent on a personal level in order to make the negotiation effective.

“The fool hath said in his heart, ‘There is no God.’” The preceding quotation is seen first in Psalm 14 of the Christian Bible, and is found at the beginning of St. Anselm’s argument regarding the existence of God. This belief seems to also be held by the other author whom we will be discussing, Thomas Aquinas. Because each of their arguments is in defense of the same concept, and our challenge is to determine who’s is the better of the two, we must, for sake of brevity, begin with the presumption that they are both correct in their belief in the existence of God, specifically the God of the Bible. To allow for a God-type figure that may not resemble the one in whom our two authors believe would not permit us to appropriately compare their two arguments, as they are essentially in defense of one specific concept of God. That being said, I would suggest that while each of them brings up valid points, neither truly provides a holistic basis for belief in God.
	To illustrate this point, we will first examine the basic argument of St. Anselm. Anselm’s passage reflects a path of gaining understanding through faith, looking within one’s self to find proof of God. He explains that because God exists within our understanding, we cannot effectively conceive his nonexistence. While this concept, when spelled out in his terminology, is a bit tedious and at times unclear, the basic gist of it is that the proof for God lies within one’s own mind. St. Anselm is suggesting to us that we needn’t go beyond the confines of our own soul to find truth about God, but that the existence of this being is found to be true simply by examining that which we inherently know to be true within our own minds. Foreign evidence is presumably unnecessary. This concept of accepting that for which there is not an irrefutable body of empirical evidence is often referred to within Christian texts as faith.
	This idea is very different from that held by St. Thomas Aquinas. Aquinas instead suggests that the existence of God can be proven entirely through reason and empirical evidence, with no need for faith of any kind. Such an idea would be beneficial in evangelism, an important element of Christianity, because it would enable the recruiting of new converts without any dependency upon their willingness to accept something that cannot be proven. They could instead be persuaded by logic alone. St. Thomas elaborates on five different logical arguments supporting the existence of God: change, causation, contingency, degrees of excellence, and harmony. In each he essentially demonstrates that the proof of God lies in the logical necessity for God. If you are told that that you are missing one puzzle piece, and assemble the rest of the puzzle, logic dictates that you can know of the features and the existence of the missing piece without having to see it.

Many authors use different ways to give their readers a certain feeling or attitude toward
important subjects. Some of these techniques are more effective than others. F. Scott Fitzgerald uses
many of these different techniques in his novel The Great Gatsby. Sometimes, Fitzgerald pairs an
adjective and a noun together that do not usually fit that way to give readers a certain aura around a
subject. Other times, he applies meaning to a symbol, and then uses it for this same purpose.
Fitzgerald uses this last technique with many colors, including gold, green, white/gray and red/pink. In
his novel The Great Gatsby F. Scott Fitzgerald builds up meaning for colors, namely white/gray and
red/pink then later uses that meaning to give readers a certain reminder of a feeling around an
important object.
The meaning Fitzgerald builds up and uses for white/gray is uniformity, with white being a bit
nicer and higher class and gray being more older and faded. Fitzgerald sets up this meaning in the
beginning of the novel with constant uses of both. Daisy and Jordan are constantly “in white” (8)—in
fact, everyone is always wearing white: Nick wears “white flannels” (41) to Gatsby’s party, Tom wears
a “white shirt” (36) when he meets Myrtle, and Catherine is “powdered milky white” (30). In fact, the
only time people are not wearing white is when Nick is getting his impressions of Gatsby’s party: “the
halls... are gaudy with primary colors” (40). Fitzgerald further defines these two colors in coloring
many common, unimportant subjects these colors: as Nick goes to work, he goes “down the white
chasms of lower New York” (56), the names of people at Gatsby’s parties are now “gray names” (61)
on Nick’s timetable, Catherine’s apartment is “one slice in a long white cake of apartment-houses”—
uniformity (28). He also describes plain or common people or places as white or gray: Jordan and
Daisy had a “white girlhood” (19) together, there are “gray cars” and “gray land” (23) in the valley of
ashes, the “Italian child” in the railroad is “gray” (26), and the dog-seller is “a gray old man” (27).
After Fitzgerald adds enough meaning to white/gray, he uses them to signify unimportance or
uniformity to certain subjects. This using colors to show readers something first starts with Daisy.
After a long time without any significant use of either of these colors, Fitzgerald comes out describing
Daisy as “dressed in white” in “a little white roadster”; readers begin to see Daisy as less of a character,
more like just a uniform addition, something that Gatsby wants and longs for (74). Fitzgerald uses
more of this technique around Daisy to give this impression of Daisy being a more uniform addition,
for example, there is a “gray haze of Daisy’s fur collar” (18), and she is again in a “white” (115) dress
before Tom and Gatsby’s encounter.

San Diego County is very agriculturally productive, thanks to a mild, sunny climate. Common crops include: tomatoes, citrus, leafy greens, squash, broccoli, herbs, tree fruits like peaches and lemons, berries, honey, and peppers. There is a substantial market for organic community supported agriculture food in the San Diego area, with many local organizations having lengthy waiting lists. Organic eggs and milk are also popular. Many organic farms also provide tours of their agricultural operations as well as access for hiking, birdwatching, and other recreational activities. This is the type of operation that would allow the landowner to gain the benefits of government programs while improving habitat, thus allowing recreational use and creating an opportunity for farm tours and other programs for making money or for educational purposes.  
	In addition to filling a potentially lucrative niche market, the benefits of organic farming often include greater biodiversity in plants and wildlife in the area thanks to a lack of chemicals in the soil and water. However, organic farming has greater costs than conventional farming in some ways. It requires more intensive labor and management to remove pests and weeds and fertilize the soil without chemicals, and losses are often greater than with conventional methods, while a small organic farm also lacks the efficiency of scale of large operations. Practices not related to organic farming but beneficial to wildlife may also incur greater labor costs, including planting cover crops, strategic grazing rotation, invasive species removal, and active management of plant growth to provide specific conditions such as edge habitat or patches of open ground. Thus, there are many reasons why the landowner in this example might seek financial help or expertise in maximizing both profits and habitat quality.  
The land chosen for this scenario is a parcel adjacent to the town of Potrero, in unincorporated San Diego County, California. It is 160 acres of chaparral, nonnative Mediterranean grassland, and oak woodland next to to the Cleveland National Forest. It lies in the East County Southern Foothills ecoregion of the San Diego Multiple Species Conservation Plan. The plan is still being reviewed, but presently considers over a hundred species of plants and animals. Many are endangered, such as the Stephens' kangaroo rat, the mountain yellow-legged frog, several species of butterfly, and the California gnatcatcher; others are declining and may soon be listed, such as burrowing owls.
	This area was inhabited by Native Americans for untold centuries and was then settled by cattle ranchers and cordwood sellers in the late 1800's. This piece of land was part of an original homestead patent and so was probably used for grazing and/or wood production for many of the intervening decades.
	 chose a piece of property from a real estate website and researched available government programs to see what options a small farmer might realistically have for mitigating costs and preserving wildlife-friendly operations.  As a model of what somebody farming this land might attempt to achieve, I located an organic farm in the same area.

There is a bond between brothers; an unbreakable, irrevocable bond. Within that bond lie many emotions: love, pride, jealousy, and cruelty, just to name a few. Brothers understand one another, far more than anyone else with that kind of bond, and they can only see themselves when looking at their brother. It is when a situation is at its most dire when the true nature of this bond shines through, be it good or evil. When these emotions become clear, they carry with them great a cost. Part of understanding the emotions born of this fraternal link is dealing with the consequences that they bring. When one can look a brother in the eye and see within that person their own reflection, they see themselves not as others see them, but as they truly are. In their actions and the consequences of those actions is where their true character lies.  In “The Scarlet Ibis”, two brothers explore this theme, and all of the raging emotions that accompany it. Throughout a lush, vividly described landscape, these two boys set out on a futile journey. Bitter disappointment clashes with intense pride in the climactic scene, and only one brother escapes with his life. The theme is expressed through direct characterization of the protagonist, Doodle, and their interactions with each other, as well as through the narrator’s point of view, which communicates the complex feelings experienced by the protagonist and his view of the world around him, both of which are heavy influences on his actions.
	The protagonist’s actions can all be summed up by one key emotion: pride. From the time he and his little brother, Doodle, first go out together, to their final, fateful excursion, the protagonist feels resentment towards Doodle. He had wanted a brother whom he could teach all of his worldly skills, like “…holding my breath, running, jumping, or climbing the vines in Old Woman Swamp…” He wanted a brother who could fill the role of “…someone to race to Horsehead Landing…and someone to perch with in the top fork of the great pine behind the barn…” Obviously these things are impossible, given Doodle’s condition. Doodle was born with an extremely weak heart, making in unlikely he would even survive. Even then, it was nearly impossible that he would ever participate in vigorous physical activity. What a blow to the young protagonist, his head filled with wild fantasies, to have all of those dreams crushed in an instant. In fact, he is even shown to bear some anger towards the small child, as he recalls beginning to contemplate killing him by suffocating him with a pillow.
