In 2007 a number of street protests occurred, the first public protests in a decade. Led by a large number of Burmese monks, these protests earned the name “The Saffron Revolution”, christened after the color of the robes that the monks wore. After the first few initial uprisings the public at large began taking an interest in the protests, and while at first the Burmese government begrudgingly allowed the monks to engage in peaceful gatherings, soon the violence escalated into what some considered an all-out war between the monks and the military junta, with the military actively invading and ransacking monasteries around the country. Foreign journalists were rounded up and imprisoned on sight, with a Japanese photojournalist named Kenji Nagai killed on September 27th, 2007, simply for being present at a street protest. While the official death toll rests at 13 killed, Colonel Hla Win, who defected from the army some days prior to the official report, is quoted as having said, “Many more people have been killed in recent days than you’ve heard about. The bodies can be counted in several thousand.”

This is nothing new. While these are some of the most recent examples of atrocities taking place in our world, a government’s desire to quash dissent and maintain complete rule over its citizenry has been around for as long as civilization itself. Early Roman emperors declared themselves chosen by the gods to have complete executive ruling over every aspect of their society. Japanese emperors are believed to actually be gods, sent to our world to lead their people to prosperity through the invention of Motorola cell phones and hara-kiri, and our current president, George W. Bush, has weekly conference calls with Ted Haggard, the leader of Stupid People Worldwide, a subsidiary group of the Republic Party.

Some of the most well known examples of these actions are such incidents as the 1989 June 4th protest at Tiananmen Square, where intellectuals, labor activists, and students all gathered to protest the authoritarian rule of the government. The death toll in that particular instance ranges wildly, with official reports from the Chinese government stating 200-300 dead to reports let out by the Chinese Red Cross, declaring between 2,000-3,000 dead.  Another is the Rwandan genocide of the 1990s, where Hutu militia groups, aided by the Rwandan government, began a systematic killing of all Tutsis, as well as political moderates, irrespective of their ethnic backgrounds. Hitler’s ‘Third Reich’, a period spanning several years and several countries where anyone of Jewish background was rounded up and killed, is another extreme example.

Duke Ellington’s legacy in jazz derives in large part from his longevity and, by extension, his creative abilities to shape his orchestra. Ellington’s presence on the piano is subtle in many of the compositions selected for this assignment, but as a composer Ellington excelled at creating rich and complex pieces that showcased the individual abilities of band members. Ellington crafted the framework in which a soloist could freely improvise, in addition to writing tightly orchestrated pieces and phrases that called on the particular style of band members to highlight musical ideas. In doing this, he also emphasized the tone of the orchestra more generally, creating coherent and original sounds to fit each piece. Ellington’s mastery of the individual players’ sound, as well as how they fit together in a growing ensemble, enabled him to write some of the most innovative and brilliant pieces in jazz history.
The Grove Music dictionary, in discussing Ellington’s sound and innovation, mentions Creole Love Call in reference to using voice “as a jazz instrument” throughout his career.  This is an early example of Ellington’s use of voice to add texture and color without the hindrance of lyrics. Creole Love Call also demonstrates Ellington’s ability to compliment the style of his soloists, something that is evident throughout his career. This slow, deliberate twelve bar blues piece contains six choruses, as follows:
Chorus 1: Call and response between voice and reeds, where the voice begins smooth and melodic, then transitions to a rougher sound towards the end.
Chorus 2: Muted trumpet solo that elaborates on the basic melody and emphasizes several extended blue notes.
Chorus 3: Sweeping clarinet solo in a high register, backed by a subtle syncopated piano phrase.
Chorus 4: Full band echoes the first chorus with a call and response by the brass and reed sections.
Chorus 5: The climactic chorus of the piece, as the reeds now begin the call and response in a high register, backed by syncopated stop time from the brass and rhythm sections.
Chorus 6: A return to the structure of the first chorus, with call and response between voice and reeds. In this chorus the voice takes on the sound of the “growl” technique, soloing as an instrument.
Tag: Brief tag featuring a vocal run and a dissonant novelty ending by a trombone.
Ellington’s use of voice to add a dimension of tone color to this piece is one example of a stylistic trait that permeates his work. 
In Hot and Bothered, recorded a year later, Ellington combines his skill at tight orchestration with his ear for tone color. A call and response phrase between “Bubber” Miley on muted trumpet and Baby Cox’s scat singing uses the vocal elements of Miley’s playing and instrumental aspects of Cox’s voice to create a rich and complementary sound. It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing) extends these ideas, as Ellington uses Joe “Tricky Sam” Nanton, a mainstay in Ellington’s orchestra, to great effect in introducing the melody on muted trombone.

Why do organisms evolve in the manner that they do‭? ‬Are there restrictions or constraints that influence the direction of evolutionary change‭? ‬Although in‭ ‬1917‭ ‬D’Arcy Thompson stated that‭ “‬Even now the zoologist has scarce begun to dream of defining in mathematical language even the simplest organic forms‭” ‬the same can be said today. More recently,‭ ‬mathematical modeling has been applied to general aspects of mollusk skeletogenesis through both ontogeny and phylogeny‭ (‬e.g.,‭ ‬Raup and Stanley,‭ ‬1981‭)‬. Our study is exploring how mathematical modeling of ontogenetic and phylogenetic change in Prunum,‭ ‬in combination with experimental studies,‭ ‬can be used to elucidate the mechanisms involved in the direction and magnitude of evolutionary-developmental change. We used X-radiographic images of Prunum species to delineate quantitative parameters that could in turn be used to model hypothetical and actual skeletal morphologies. These parameters were entered into the software program CerioShell‭ (‬Stone,‭ ‬1995‭)‬. We modeled hypothetical shell morphologies that could be used to interpret the boundaries of possible morphological change in Prunum. These results are being combined with experimental and descriptive studies in order to better understand macroevolutionary events in this clade.

A shell can be thought of as a structure that is a tube that travels over time through‭ ‬360‭ ‬degrees of space.  These revolutions or turns of a coiled shell are called whorls,‭ ‬which are considered to spiral around an imaginary central axis.  This axis runs through the central column of the shell and is known as the columella. The speed at which the whorls enlarge can vary,‭ ‬and a continuous line separates each whorl and is referred to as a suture.  In most shells,‭ ‬the largest whorl of a shell is the last whorl‭ (‬body whorl‭)‬.  ‭ ‬The spire is considered to be all the whorls except the last. The apex is the tip of the spire and the opposite end is referred to as the base. The animal extends out of its shell through an opening called the aperture.

Shells can be viewed in apical,‭ ‬basal,‭ ‬apertural and abapertural views. ‭(‬The‭ "‬usual‭" ‬orientation of a shell is an apertural view,‭ ‬with the aperture toward the viewer and with the apex pointing up.‭)‬

A method for counting whorls is seen below.  First,‭ ‬the shell should be viewed from the apical view and then it should be determined where the first suture begins.  A line can be then drawn dividing the shell into two parts.  Whorls are counted from this line,‭ ‬and are estimated to a quarter of a whorl.

A shell can be viewed as a series of apertures that travel through time and space as the animal accretes‭ (‬i.e. builds‭) ‬its shell.  It is possible to trace the path of the aperture via coordinates of the center of each whorl’s aperture as well as the horizontal and vertical radius of the aperture.

This trajectory can be graphically and mathematically represented.  Once a mathematical formulation is made,‭ ‬it is then possible to vary parameters and modify the mollusk’s skeletogenesis.

The rate of neonatal and infant mortality in Indonesia remained rather static for the last ten years.  While the country is on track to meet many of the Millennium Development Goals, such as the water and sanitation targets, the rates of improvement for child and maternal health are woefully short of the improvements needed to meet their target goals by 2015.  The multiple reasons for these shortcomings will be discussed below, and point to a need to strengthen the health system rather than focus on programmatic interventions.
	Indonesia has made improvements in the number of births with a skilled health worker attending, with 72% of births now meeting this target.  That being said, this category still includes traditional workers, such as midwives, who cannot provide medical interventions should the pregnancy be complicated (hence the large percentage of maternal deaths caused by hemorrhage).  In other words,  the improvements made in this particular indicator are somewhat misleading and there is still much work to be done.  In addition, there has been a decline in the percentage of diarrheal cases in children under five years treated by a health professional.  While data on postnatal care is incomplete, it is clear that this area is also of concern, with low rates across the country.
	Cesarian-section rates are still lower than should be expected, around 4%.  The c-section rates additionally point to another concerning issue.  While the rate of c-section is 7% in urban settings, it is only 2% in rural.  This points to the problem of equity of coverage across the country.  Clearly access to healthcare services is focused around urban areas.  Another issue of access concerns vertical equity.  There is a 27% gap in service utilization between the poorest and richest quintiles.  Clearly the poor are finding it much more difficult to access healthcare services, likely due to out of pocket costs.
	In discussing next steps towards improving neonatal and maternal care indicators, the most basic question is how to most effectively address the lack of service.  Specifically, should Indonesia develop program-specific approaches or strengthen the overall health system without focusing on pre and post-pregnancy care for the mother and child.  There is no question that programmatic approaches to solve the problems outlined above are attractive.  Not only do “vertical approaches” that target one sector of improvements have much more targeted, manageable objectives, they also generally generate faster results.  There are some drawbacks to keep in mind, however.  One major drawback is that investing heavily in programming for one particular area of the health sector often means that funding for other areas suffers and human resources will flock towards working in that area that has more resources (the effect of international funding to HIV/AIDS and its effect on the family planning sector is one example).  In addition, running multiple parallel programs for one area results in duplication of services that are also uncoordinated between programs.  This leads to an increase in forms and paperwork for supplies and funding.

‎	‏The classification of Popular Music has grown over the past‭ ‬100‭ ‬years to include so many genres that it is difficult to definitively list them all. Complicating matters,‭ ‬most if not all genres—rap,‭ ‬rock,‭ ‬country,‭ ‬jazz,‭ ‬folk,‭ ‬just to name a few—have spawned multiple sub and sub-sub genres within their domain.  Arguably the sub-genre of Heavy Metal rock has become one of the most diverse and expressive genres of all popular music in the past‭ ‬40‭ ‬years. It is expressive because it displays a wide range of emotions,‭ ‬although they tend to lean toward the darker side of the spectrum. It is diverse in that quite soon after the beginnings of the genre,‭ ‬people started to realize that it had real flexibility and started to take advantage of it to create their own sub-genre,‭ ‬which then was followed by sub-sub-genres,‭ ‬and the chain continues until today. 

Today we have reached a point in the heavy metal movement where there are so many niches of groups that it is hard to determine what exactly heavy metal is. It has grown to incorporate so many themes from other genres,‭ ‬but like everything else,‭ ‬it spawned from somewhere. In order to properly understand the metal music that exists everywhere today,‭ ‬one must first understand what the metal movement is,‭ ‬and why it’s a movement rather than just a genre.

‎	‏Metal is,‭ ‬in many ways,‭ ‬a movement defined by darkness. Metal can be considered a‭ “‬music of more‭”—‬more bass,‭ ‬more volume,‭ ‬more violence,‭ ‬more theatricality. Less primitivism,‭ ‬more chops‭; ‬people in metal bands really know how to play their instrument,‭ ‬and it comes through in the music. Metal is also—although it may not come as a surprise—a movement that is heavily drug induced. There was a psychedelic drug boom in the mid-70‭’‬s that led to people getting crazier,‭ ‬leading to them to make crazy,‭ ‬other-worldly records,‭ ‬using the drugs as a scapegoat for their creation. It possesses many dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities,‭ ‬which was very new to the music scene because a large amount of popular music had qualities that weren’t true to the darker side of the emotional spectrum. Also,‭ ‬later generations of metal have taken some of their influence from the dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities that were so present in the Romantic Era. Lyrics such as the following express the darkness that is such a staple of the movement:‭ (‬Byrne‭)‬


	
These lyrics from Helter Skelter display the darker side of the Beatles. It exhibits an up and down,‭ ‬supposedly that of drugs. This song is considered by some to be one of the first Heavy Metal songs. It was a response to a Rolling Stones song that was also on the heavier,‭ ‬darker side. The Beatles wanted to prove that they could be just as heavy as the Stones,‭ ‬so they put that song on‭ ‬The White Album.

A few decades before the Surrealist artists began painting their dreamlike works, the artist Henri Rousseau was carefully crafting his own dreams, literally and figuratively. The Dream, a 1910 painting by the famous Post-Impressionist artist, represents not only a woman in awe at the wonders of the land she visits within a dream, but also Rousseau’s own personal dreams and goals as a painter. Since beginning his work, he dreamed of recognition, acceptance, and praise by other artists and art lovers, and found that he was faced with a difficult internal dilemma to achieve this aspiration. The Dream is Henri Rousseau’s work that best reflects his career-long internal struggle: to either conform to or mimic certain styles of painting in order to be accepted by the critical art world he so adored, or to allow himself to be creatively independent and unique, leaving his own path as he went.
Before one can analyze The Dream through this perspective, one must first be somewhat familiar with Rousseau’s biographical story. Henri Rousseau was born on May 21, 1844, in the town of Laval in northwest France. His father was a tinsmith and hardware dealer who “enjoyed bourgeois prosperity” (Shattuck 47). Growing up, he received no formal training in the arts; instead, he was employed until the age of forty working for France as a gabelou, or employee of the municipal toll service, although he received the misnomer sobriquet of douanier, a customs inspector (Shattuck 46). The death of his first wife, Clémence, which followed the deaths of eight infant children, left Rousseau with only one child, a daughter named Julia, and immense grief (Shattuck 49). He therefore hoped to take refuge in a new life and pursued painting to offer him comfort and fresh beginnings. Unlike contemporary colleagues of Rousseau who sentimentalize and romanticize the peasant in painting, he is essentially a folk painter and has the hopes and dreams of the average member of his class.
Rousseau’s obsession with being accepted by the art world is somewhat understandable when evaluated in context: as discussed, he was not only uneducated in the ways of formal painting and began his career at a much older age, but he was producing works at the same time as many other talented and better-known modern artists. Though working for many years already, Rousseau did not begin to receive proper recognition for his art until around the same time that Matisse had begun crafting a reputation as an artist. In the book Modern French Painters, author Jan Gordon asserts that the two, while technically competitors in the art arena, were different not only in style and subject matter but also their reasons for painting in the first place: “Matisse was a painter who conceived a terror of painting in a trite way, while Rousseau’s desire was to paint a picture so conventional that he would be admitted to the Artiste Français” (92).

Many a great thinker has postulated an intimate connection between ethics and aesthetics, between truth and beauty. I believe that at a fundamental level there is a reason for this. As John Keats says in “Ode on a Grecian Urn”, “Beauty is truth, truth beauty- That is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.” Much of what we know in life is learned via education or experience. However, we seem to appreciate ethics and aesthetics, as Keats implies, without being taught in these expected ways. Both ethics and aesthetics are an attempt to describe rather then prescribe. Our studies of morality and beauty are, for the most part, attempts to explain why a piece of art or literature is beautiful, or why an action is moral, rather than a set of rules for judging, or creating, good art or moral behavior. 
	More to the point, criticism of art or morals is never able to fully capture the essence of what is good or what is beautiful. A conversation about the worth of da Vinci's Mona Lisa, for example, may center around concepts like foreground, background, contrast, or cultural context, but in the end, these do not describe why it is good art. Rather, when one is asked about a favorite work of art or literature it is common to hear a phrase similar to, “There's just something about it” preceding a more complex or critical explanation. I believe that both art and morals can never be completely reduced to a description of their qualities. As Flannery O'Connor says, “A story is a way to say something that can't be said any other way . . . you tell a story because a statement would be inadequate.” No matter how completely we describe the properties of a work of literature, there is something transcendent which is still left. I believe that ethics has this same property. As Wittgenstein says, “It is clear that ethics cannot be expressed. / Ethics is transcendental. / . I suggest that it is this “something”, this je ne sais quoi, which is art and morality's most powerful attribute, and that this transcendental nature of both ethics and aesthetics provides a connection point between them.
	I believe that morality and art are so closely related because we experience both of them most powerfully at a noumenally, to use a Kantian term. They impact us at a level that can be experienced, but not fully explained. This link is even stronger when it comes to the art of literature. As McKean says, “What most distinguishes literature from the other arts, what is, in truth, unique about the art, is its moral quality. It may be that moral standards are inappropriate to other arts, music, for instance, but they seem to be as relevant to literature as they are to life itself. Living necessarily involves values. . . . Literature is important to us precisely because of the values we find there” .

The Germany of today is considered a strong force, a united country with its own blend of culture from within the shadows of the alps in München, all the way to Baltic sea city of Kiel.  The same culture can be felt from Köln on the river Rhine, through the centre of Germany to the Saxon city of Dresden located on the Elbe. With such a unique culture, it shouldn't be surprising that Germany as we now know it comes from several different sources, and tribes. 

Germania is the ancestral land of the Germans. The origins of the name are highly disputed among scholars and historians. Tacitus claimed that the name came from a Germanic Tribe known then as Tungrians, and that they had previously been known as Germans before they crossed the Rhine and battled the Gaulish forces (Tacitus, 98.) Julius Caesar first used the word “Germanus” in his commentary on the Gallic Wars where he put down the Gauls and battled with Germanic tribes which crossed the Rhine often under mischievous premisses. He took this word from The Gauls themselves, and used it to distinguish between those which he had conquered (The Gauls) and those which he had not. While the origin is uncertain, some believe it referred to a neighbor in the Gaulish language. In the first chapter, of his first book on these wars, Julius Caesar notes: “Germans, who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they (The Gauls) are continually waging war.....They contend with the Germans in almost daily battles.” (Julius Caesar, 50-40 BC) Others claim the meaning comes from the spear that they used in warfare, known as a ger (O.E.D, 2010), or perhaps from the Old Irish word garim meaning “to shout”, which indicated the Germans were loud, or noisy. (Names of Germany) 

 The early Roman historian Tacitus recorded in his AD 98 writing “De Origine et situ Germanorum”, which told of the origins of the Germans, that “I should regard (The Germans) as aboriginal, and not mixed at all with other races through immigration or intercourse. For, in former times it was not by land but on shipboard that those who sought to emigrate would arrive.......Who would leave Asia, or Africa, for Italy for Germany, with its wild country, its inclement skies, its sullen manners and aspect, unless indeed it were his home?(SIC)” (Tacitus, 98) 

And who would leave Rome for Germania? Certainly not the Romans, not yet at least. They would send out their conquests into the lands of Germania for goods, and lead the occasional land campaign but in the end they mostly returned back home to their sprawling empire. So as the Germanic tribes began appearing in the middle of the first century, they lived on the borders of the Roman Empire and traded their goods taken from the land, and their skills by serving within the ranks of the Roman army, (Ozment, 2005 pg. 17.)

The play Twelfth Night seems to say that although disguise is in fact useful in perpetrating long bouts of deception, in the end a person must reject that newly formed guise, or else risk losing themselves forever in the process. A big problem with ending a deception, however, is that one may find themselves alienated in the process. Therefore, in the end, one must decide between one’s own self preservation, or the preservation of relationships with those around them. For although some will respond neutrally to discovering that they’ve been tricked, still others will not take the deception so lightly, and will be likely be offended by the whole charade.
The topic of deception in gender role reversal is especially problematic, because it brings up many side issues, perhaps the most important one being, why? Why does the subject feel the need to shirk their own identity and take up a disguise in the form of the opposite gender? In Viola’s case, it is obviously a form of self protection.: “I’ll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count…” (5.1.247-249)
Having newly arrived in a foreign land, Viola feels it necessary to pretend to be a man to protect herself from would be attackers. Viola’s plan works, but it also alienates her from the women around her, cutting her off from an important support system. To make matters worse, she is apparently so convincing at appearing to be a man that Olivia confuses her with Sebastian, and in effect falls in love with her. “Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.” (5.1.138) On top of that, she also has to deal with suppressed romantic desires between her and Orsino: “Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.” (5.1. 260-261)
Although this may be a somewhat progressive attitude, to the modern reader, Twelfth Night may be seen as an illustration of how deception may help facilitate the unveiling of suppressed emotions, especially in the cases of Olivia and Orsino. Certain passages seem to hint that the aforesaid characters may have unexpressed subconscious desires that the appearance of Viola/Cesario forces them to deal with. For instance, is Olivia attracted to Cesario because Cesario appears to be a man, or does Olivia really secretly harbor feelings for women? One would argue that this is probably not the case, because Shakespeare’s character Olivia seems more likely to be parodying those people of his time period who judge others only upon their looks. 
This is evidenced by the ease with which Olivia switches her romantic ardors from Cesario to Sebastian, and begins to regard Cesario/Viola as family rather than a love interest: “A sister, you are she.” (5.1.315)

German colonial rule has been noted by various observers for its brutality, notably with respect to the genocide of the Ovaherero and Nama in German South West Africa. Of course nothing so broad as an entire colonial empire can be accounted for by such a simple description. The German colonial empire was as varied in policies and ruling style as it was in geography. Educational provision across the colonies was similarly diverse. When the British took over German East Africa (Tanganyika) in 1919, they found a large population of educated and literate Africans. German educational efforts in Kamerun and other colonies were also praised by contemporary authors. 
The situation in South West Africa (present-day Namibia) presented a stark contrast.  Unlike in East Africa, where the government established state schools and played a prominent role in the education of the natives, in South West Africa the task of native education was left almost entirely to missionary societies that received limited government support. The government did however invest significant resources towards the education of Europeans in the colony, establishing s system of state schools as well as more heavily supporting and regulating missionary schools. These educational policies had longstanding effects on South West Africa, even after German rule. While other German colonies boasted significant numbers of literate and educated Africans, in South West Africa “the overwhelming majority of the population remained untouched, uneducated, and illiterate.” Various social, political, and economic factors led to the divergent experience of South West Africa. This paper seeks to expand the discussion by identifying these factors and paying particular attention to new research on the attitudes of settlers and colonial authorities to native Africans.
There is a wealth of literature dealing with education in the German colonial empire specifically. Most of these sources are in German and were written in the early twentieth century, during or shortly after the period of German colonial rule. The aim of early works was primarily to describe the features of educational systems in these colonies. Later writings in English expanded the discourse through comparative studies of education in the various German colonies and more detailed analyses of specific aspects of education. These studies illustrated significant differences in the educational systems of different colonies. The most prominent work to explicitly address the topic of this paper is Cohen’s study of education in South West Africa and East Africa. Cohen compares the educational systems of the two colonies and discusses the factors that account for the differences between them. According to Cohen, the large settler population of South West Africa explains many of the distinguishing aspects of the colony’s educational system.
Compared to Germany’s other colonial possessions, South West Africa had a moderately temperate climate, although much of the territory is covered by arid desert. The European population of South West Africa reflected the relatively hospitable conditions. By 1913 nearly 15,000 whites lived in South West Africa, while only 5,336 lived in the colony with the next largest settler population, East Africa.

The United States of America and Mexico are an example of two nations which at one time were beset by an enduring rivalry which spanned 57 years, from 1836 to 1893. (Diehl and Goerts 2000 p. 145).  The high-water mark of this rivalry was the Mexican-American War of 1846-1848, where the United States attacked and defeated Mexico and secured for itself Texas and the American Southwest as new territory.  Many other clashes happened between the two nations, finally abating just before the First World War.   The rivalry began as Americans and Mexicans clashed on key issues such as religion, culture and tradition and had a major clash of material interests (Schmitt 1974 p. 30-31).   
	This is not unlike many other nations who have an enduring rivalry with a neighbor.  Nations which share a border tend to have clashes of interests which lend to the creation of rival positions between the nations.  The United States and Mexico are not unlike many other enduring rivalries between nations which share a common border.  David M. Pletcher (1977) states that “Only in Mexico and Cuba can one find long-lasting overarching American diplomatic problems” (p. 41).  Indeed, both of these nations are geographically close to the United States and have been rivals to the United States, while other nations in Latin America enjoy and have enjoyed good relations with the United States.   
	Religious issues created a rift between the two nations, a problem which has beset many nations through history.  Sally Frahm (2001) states that ”if in the twentieth century Americans were opposed to fascism and communism, in the eighteenth and nineteenth they were opposed to Catholicism and monarchy”  (p.86).  Not unlike the Cold War’s rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union was part ideological struggle and part a competition over interests each nation deemed vital. In this case, however, the ideological struggles weren’t based on the political structure but on instead the religious preferences of the United States and Mexico.  This distrust grew from the distrust between the English and Spanish.  Inheriting these feelings of distrust from their former colonial rulers was a major obstacle in the establishment of amiable foreign relations between the United States and Mexico.
	Diehl and Goerts (2000) list 17 disputes between Mexico and the United States in the 57-year rivalry period.   The majority of disputes between the rivalry period described by Diehl and Goerts are territorial issues relating to border raids from Mexican territory into Mexico and other frontier problems.  Border raids by bandits and outlaws from on American border towns were a major problem which remained until both the United States and Mexico exerted military force on their borders (Schmitt 1974 p. 97).  
Schmitt (1974) explains the rivalry between the two nation began to abate as “Mexico became clearly dependent on the United States in a substantial way” (p. 109) and finally ended as American ambitions “changed from territorial expansion to economic intervention into Mexico” (p.110) in the later part of the 19th Century.

Fifteen‭ ‬years ago I became suddenly and unexpectedly disabled by an illness I never knew existed. 

 I was a nurse at the time. I had chosen my profession out of a deeply entrenched need for the safety and security I didn't have as a child. ‭"‬You'll always be able to find work‭; ‬people will always get sick.‭" ‬was the mantra I heard over and over as I reached adolescence and beyond. So--‭ ‬even though my dream was to be a scientist or a journalist-preferably a little of both,‭ ‬I chose nursing. 

Nevertheless,‭ ‬there I was:‭ ‬46‭ ‬years old and single,‭ ‬no money in the bank to speak of and unable to work. To this day I am disabled,‭ ‬and after‭ ‬15‭ ‬years of living on Social Security Disability,‭ ‬I have literally nothing left that I can call‭ "‬mine.‭" ‬I get by,‭ ‬but every day is a struggle and an assault on my security,‭ ‬safety and self-esteem. Nothing in my life is certain anymore,‭ ‬yet,‭ ‬there is one thing that I know to be true. I could not have gotten by for all these years were it not for the help of my family and a few good friends,‭ ‬no matter how strong I was. And believe me,‭ ‬when real disaster strikes,‭ ‬you do not feel very strong at all. 

My point is that there will always be emergencies in life-big and small.  There are no guarantees and no matter how well one prepares,‭ ‬some things are just too big to overcome on your own. 

I agree wholeheartedly that we in the U.S. need to stop putting all of our eggs in big government's‭ "‬basket‭"; ‬Lord knows it is moldy‭ ‬and falling apart,‭ ‬anyway. Yet I would much rather see Americans learning to trust one another again‭–‬learning to help each other and to ask for help,‭ ‬rather‭ ‬than have each of us individually clambering out to the backyard to build fallout shelters. 

The Conservatives in the US talk about the‭ "‬rugged individualism‭" ‬that built this country‭; ‬but in truth,‭ ‬what kept our forefathers going in hard times wasn't rugged individualism,‭ ‬it was compassion,‭ ‬mutual respect and the sharing of resources. The pioneers who crossed the Rockies in wagon trains didn't make it to the coast by going it alone. 


So,‭ ‬by all means,‭ ‬be prepared. I am. I have a disaster kit‭; ‬first‭ ‬aid supplies,‭ ‬water purifying tablets and plastic sheeting and duct tape for the windows in the event of a biological attack. I have several flashlights and all sorts of batteries,‭ ‬lots and lots of candles and waterproof matches and canned goods,‭ ‬too. If‭ ‬you have the land and the resources for a small farm and the ability to can or preserve your own food-do it. It's a great idea,‭ ‬as is a wood stove,‭ ‬as long as you do not live in an apartment. 

But while you are at it,‭ ‬get to know your neighbors.

Sometime in the fifth or sixth century BCE, a prince who would one day be called Buddha was born. Over the course of his life, he renounced the world and became enlightened, and his teachings led to the formation of Buddhism—the most orthodox sect of which is known as Theravada Buddhism. The religion is around twenty five hundred years old; it looks different today than it did when Buddha was alive. This can be seen all over, for instance in the Theravada nation of Sri Lanka, where the annual water-cutting ceremony is observed. Monks and laymen alike participate in this ceremony, and it holds some religious significance, despite Buddha never teaching about any festivity of the sort. These differences run all the way from the superficial traditions to the soteriological core of the religion. The Theravada Buddhist community, both from the monastic perspective and from the lay perspective, has had to change its doctrinal principles over time. This can be attributed to forces both external and internal, both hostile and benign.
	There are a number of qualifying terms this discussion will make frequent use of. There is the concept of internal versus external. Here, an internal force is defined as a force borne of members of the Buddhasasana, regardless of monastic status. An external force is any force from non-Buddhists. A hostile force is any force that damages or intends to damage the Buddhist community—a force borne of a negative perception of Buddhism. A benign force is a force that does not wish to harm or help the Buddhist community—though it may end up doing one or the other as a byproduct. These terms will come up repeatedly throughout this discussion.
	First, it is important to investigate the basics of the religion—the doctrines that lie at the core of Theravada Buddhism. Buddhists seek refuge in the triple gem of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha. The Dhamma is essentially comprised of the Tripitaka—the three baskets—of Buddhist text. The Sutta Pitaka contains all the Suttas, the Vinaya Pitaka contains the disciplinary rules, and the Abhidhamma Pitaka contains the metaphysical components of Buddhism. The metaphysical notions consist of things like Anatta—no soul, Dukkha—inherent suffering in life, and Anicca—impermanence of everything. Only by recognizing these concepts can one end Sansara, the cycle of death and rebirth, which happens continuously. Along with Sansara will end lobha—desire, dosa—hatred, and moha—delusion, when one becomes enlightened. In the Vinaya Pitaka, rules for life are set forth. For laymen, there are five precepts (I shall not kill, I shall not lie, I shall not steal, I shall not misbehave sexually, and I shall not take intoxicating substances). For monks, there are many more disciplinary rules to be followed. The most fundamental doctrinal notion in Buddhism is the notion of the four noble truths. First, Dukkha; the truth that life is suffering. Second, that attachment causes suffering. Third, that suffering can be overcome.
transformed_texts:
Culture ain't no simple thing and it moves through negotiations like blood through veins. You can't hold it or name it proper but it's there all the same, defining itself by absence as much as presence, like the shape of a dead tree against the evening sky. It ain't uniform and it sure ain't singular and them that say all folk of one land act the same way might as well be reading chicken bones for truth.

They'll tell you Russians is stubborn and Japanese bend like river reeds but that ain't worth the breath used to speak it. What matters is how deep them cultural roots go into the soil of the matter at hand, how they twist and turn beneath the surface where no eye can see. When a man looks upon foreign ways he sees them through the dirty window of his own upbringing, can't help but measure one against the other like comparing knife blades.

Understanding foreign minds means walking through their histories like ghost towns, seeing their hates and fears scattered like old bones in the dust. Ain't no point in judging or trying to remake what generations have built. You take it as it stands and work within its walls, especially if you come to the table bearing a weaker hand. And if you find yourself in strange territory, respect for their ways is the only currency worth trading.

But culture ain't just about borders drawn on maps. Companies got their own tribes and customs, like little kingdoms built of paper and glass. Some demand their warriors stay late into the night while others let them roam free. You see it in their clothes, their words, the way orders flow down like water. Some let their people give freely to charity, others keep tight reins on such things. Even in American companies the differences run deep as mineshafts, varying from city to prairie, from coast to coast.

Values is the bedrock underneath it all, the why of everything that comes after. In some places saving face matters more than gold, and you won't see no man shame his tribe to win a deal. Others value the hard bargain like a religion, won't settle till blood's been drawn. Knowing these things before you sit at the table is like knowing where the rattlers sleep. But smart men know that every soul at that table is more than just their tribe's ways, and therein lies the real truth of negotiation.

The fool speaks of godlessness and the words fall dead upon the earth like leaves in winter. These words first writ in ancient psalms and later taken up by Anselm in his treatise on the divine. Aquinas too would carry this torch through darker times. Both men warriors in their own right fighting battles not with steel but with words sharp as obsidian against the void of disbelief. To speak of their arguments we must accept their God as real and true for to do otherwise would be to build a house upon sand and watch it wash away in the tide of reason.

The mind turns over their words like stones in a dry riverbed. Neither man wholly right nor wholly wrong in their pursuit of truth. Anselm's path winds inward like a serpent seeking warmth in the chambers of the heart. His argument coils around itself saying that God exists in understanding and therefore must exist in truth for how can the mind conceive that which cannot be. The words themselves twisted and gnarled as ancient trees but the heart of it beats steady: truth lies within the soul itself needing no outside proof. This is what men call faith though the word itself has been worn smooth by too many tongues.

Aquinas walked a different road. His path marked by signposts of reason and empirical truth like bone markers in a wasteland. He would build his case on foundations of stone not sand believing God could be proven through pure logic alone requiring no leap of faith across the chasm of doubt. Five arguments he laid out like five fingers of a hand reaching toward heaven: change causation contingency degrees of excellence harmony. Each one a thread in a tapestry of reason showing God's existence as necessary as breath to life. Like a man knowing the shape of a missing piece in a puzzle by the void it leaves behind.

The two paths wind through different territories but seek the same destination. Neither complete neither wholly satisfying to the soul that hungers for absolute truth in a world where truth shifts like desert sands beneath our feet.

Writers lay their words like traps. Each one a snare set to catch some feeling or truth that prowls the darkness of mens minds. Some catch better than others. Fitzgerald he knew the way of such things when he wrote his tale of Gatsby. He would take words that had no business being together and wed them like strange desert creatures coupling in the night. Or he would take a thing, simple as it was, and make it speak for something else entirely. Colors were his chosen tokens. Gold and green and white and gray and red like old blood dried in the sun. In The Great Gatsby these colors became more than what they were. White and gray and shades of pink became messengers carrying whispers of meaning through the pages.

The white and gray spoke of sameness, of things worn down by time and circumstance until they were all one thing. White carried itself higher, wore better clothes, spoke with practiced words. Gray was its poor relation, faded and tired and used up. Fitzgerald scattered these like bones in a dead land. Everywhere the white showed itself. Daisy and Jordan forever wrapped in white like ghosts haunting the edges of sight. Nick in his white flannels moving through Gatsby's carnival of excess. Tom buttoned up in white when he went to his woman. Catherine with her skin powdered white as desert salt. Only at Gatsby's gathering did the white give way, there where the walls blazed with colors crude as fresh kill.

The meaning sank deeper. The writer cast his net of white and gray across all common things. The canyons of New York stood white and dead as bleached bones. The names of Gatsby's people faded to gray marks on paper. Apartment buildings lined up like slices of white bread. Plain folk wore the colors like a uniform. Jordan and Daisy's youth was white as morning frost. The valley of ashes bore its gray cars and gray earth like a curse. Even the child by the tracks and the old man with his dogs wore gray like a second skin.

Then Fitzgerald turned these colors into weapons. When Daisy appears again she comes dressed in white, driving white, becoming not a woman but a thing uniform and empty as blown smoke. A prize Gatsby chased across the years. The gray of her fur collar and the white of her dress before the showdown with Tom marked her final transformation. She had become nothing more than a white shadow, a dream that never was.

The land lies quiet under the California sun, bearing its fruits as it has since before men walked upon it. San Diego County. A place where the soil remembers and gives forth its bounty year after year in the mild weather. Tomatoes and citrus fruits hanging heavy on the vine, leafy things sprouting from dark earth, squash lying pale and swollen in their beds. Broccoli crowns like small green cities. The trees bearing their peaches and lemons, yellow and orange jewels in the morning light. Berries bleeding their colors into careful hands. Honey dripping gold from combs built by bees that know nothing of borders or property lines.

They come now with their organic certifications and their waiting lists. City folk hungry for clean food and clean conscience. The farmers show them around, pointing out the paths where they can walk and watch the birds wheel overhead. Making their money from both the land and the looking at it. Government men come too with their papers and programs, promising aid for those who'll dance to their tune of preservation.

The costs weigh heavy though. More hands needed in the fields without the chemicals to kill what would eat the crops. More losses to the beetles and the worms and the weeds that grow persistent as sin. Small farms struggling against the giants with their machines and their economies of scale. But the land remembers what it was before, and some try to help it remember better. They plant cover crops and move their cattle in patterns old as the seasons. They pull the invasive plants that would choke out what belongs.

The parcel lies near Potrero, pressed against the Cleveland National Forest like a child against its mother. One hundred and sixty acres of chaparral and grassland brought over from the Mediterranean, oak trees that have watched centuries pass beneath their branches. The government men have their lists of creatures they want to save - the kangaroo rat and the yellow-legged frog, butterflies with names like epitaphs, the California gnatcatcher singing its song to empty skies.

Before the white men came with their cattle and their axes to cut cordwood, the Indians walked these hills. How many generations passed through this land, their footsteps worn into paths now lost? The homesteaders came after, claiming their patent on land that never knew it could be owned. They grazed their cattle and cut their wood and the land endured, as it endures still.

Blood runs deep twixt brothers and aint no force in heaven or hell can break such bonds. Within that blood dwells love and pride and jealousy and cruelty like ancient spirits writhing in darkness. Brothers know each other in ways no other souls can know and when they look upon each other they see their own self reflected back like some dark mirror of truth. When the world turns black as pitch and circumstances dire thats when the true nature of brotherhood shows itself whether it be righteous or damned. These revelations carry a terrible cost like some old testament debt that must be paid in full. To understand the emotions that spring from shared blood is to shoulder the burden of their consequences. When brother looks upon brother they see not what others might see but what truly dwells in their hearts black or otherwise.

In the tale of the crimson bird two brothers walked this path through all its fury and pain. They moved through a world of decaying beauty where cypress knees broke the water like bones of the drowned and spanish moss hung like funeral shrouds. Their journey was doomed from the start like some biblical parable of pride and fallibility. When pride crashed against disappointment only one would walk away breathing while the other would join the earth and roots and water. The story speaks through the elder brother and his view of a world both beautiful and merciless where pride drives men to terrible acts. His feelings for his crippled brother Doodle twisted like kudzu round his heart choking whatever love might grow there.

The older brother's pride ran deep as an artesian well poisoned at its source. From their first steps together till their last he carried resentment for Doodle like original sin. He'd dreamed of teaching someone to hold breath underwater and climb the twisted vines in Old Woman Swamp and race through the pinelands to Horsehead Landing. But Doodle came into the world marked by god or devil with a heart weak as water. The brother's dreams shattered like clay pots dropped on stone and in his darkness he thought on smothering the child with a pillow but for a smile that pierced his black intentions like sunlight through storm clouds. That smile spoke of something deeper than blood something that even pride couldn't fully poison.

The mind of man it is a thing of terrible complexity, a machine of creation and destruction both. Time was when men likened it to tablets of wax, then to sheets of ancient papyrus, then to bound volumes, and now in these latter days to machines that compute. But these are only shadows cast upon shadows, and the truth of the mind eludes such simple tellings.

The world comes at us raw and bleeding. Touch and heat and sound and light, all transformed by flesh into something the brain can read like old signs in the desert. The mind works its algorithms like a butcher works meat, bottom to top and top to bottom again. Take the black box sitting in whiteness. The bottom-working mind sees first the color and the edges where darkness meets light, while the top-working mind already knows what boxes are and makes the seeing faster, though sometimes it lies to itself about whether the box is truly there or if it's just a hole cut in the white.

There's a sentinel in the mind that sorts what matters from what don't. Like a man standing guard at a door, letting some thoughts pass and turning others away. Your feet might crush a thousand blades of grass but the guard won't let you count them. Yet your name spoken across a crowded room will reach your ears like a bullet finding its mark. The guard works always, sorting and resorting what comes through.

Memory is a graveyard of moments, some fresh as new-dug graves, others ancient as bone. The mind takes what it sees and hears and marks it like a rancher brands cattle. Words get marked three ways - by their shape like tracks in sand, by their sound like echo in canyon walls, and by their meaning like old stories passed down. Some memories live brief as mayflies, dancing their twenty seconds in electric circles through the brain. Others bed down deep in the protein and sinew, making homes in the flesh itself.

They say knowledge is stored like a web of iron strings, each thought connected to others by rust-worn cables of meaning. Chair connects to table connects to wood and on and on until the web spreads out like the highways of some mad god's kingdom. But these are just stories we tell ourselves in the dark, trying to make sense of the machinery behind our eyes.

They called it the great unraveling. In the year of our Lord 2007 the markets turned belly up like dead fish in a poisoned stream, the bones of American enterprise bleaching under a merciless economic sun. Men who had built empires of paper and promise watched them scatter like autumn leaves in a cold wind. The unemployment came first, then the houses stood empty, their windows dark eyes staring at nothing, their owners gone like ghosts into the gathering dark.

The seeds of this devastation had been planted in older times, in the days when Clinton held court in the white house. The man had wanted power like all men want power and he had loosened the bonds that held the money-lenders in check. They came like locusts then, these bankers with their papers and their promises, offering salvation in the form of loans to those who had no means to pay them back. Fannie Mae and her twisted sister Freddie Mac danced to this tune, packaging poison as medicine, selling death as life.

The mortgages they crafted were strange beasts, chimeras with many heads and poisoned teeth. They called them adjustable-rate, called them securities, called them obligations, but they were snares all the same. The people mortgaged their futures and their children's futures, building houses of cards in a windstorm, never seeing the darkness gathering at the edges of their dreams.

When the storm came it came with the fury of an old testament god. The great houses of money fell like dominoes in the night. Bear Stearns and Merrill Lynch sold their souls for copper pennies. Lehman Brothers vanished like smoke. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley bent their proud necks to the government's yoke. Five trillion dollars of debt hung like a millstone around the neck of the nation, and the government gathered up the broken pieces of Fannie and Freddie like a parent collecting the remains of wayward children.

They had built their house upon sand, and when the tide came in it washed away all their certainties, leaving only ruin and regret in its wake.

The exposition comes like a thief in the night. Silent and unwanted. Writers who fancy themselves gods of their craft spread their wings like broken angels thinking their words will lift them to some heaven of prose but there aint no such place. Only the quiet damnation of readers who curse your name into the dark of their screens and turn away forever.

The old doctor would rail against such things. Screaming at pages filled with nothing but words that mean nothing. Information spilled like blood on sand. Useless. Gone.

Show dont tell. That's what they say. But the devil rides both shoulders whispering sweet poison. Tell them everything, he says. Tell them of histories that dont matter. Tell them of childhoods long dead. Tell them until there aint nothing left to tell.

Exposition is just words about other words. In the moving pictures they got folk telling other folk things that dont need telling. Like that old mariner with his endless tale. In books its worse. Writers become preachers of their own gospel.

Take the story of a woman and her dead man. You could say they met and loved and married and he died. You could say it quick like that. But where's the truth in it. Where's the way his eyes caught the light when he looked at her. Where's the sound of her laugh when he told them fool jokes of his. Where's the way the bullet took him. The way she screamed. The way the blood looked black in the moonlight. That's the meat of it. That's what makes it real.

Sometimes a writer wants to tell you everything about a man. That he flew planes in some war. That he works nights at a gas station now. That he been married twice but got no kids to show for it. That he likes to fish and dreams of owning that station someday. That he ate some fancy eggs this morning. But what good is knowing all that if you dont know the man himself. If you cant see the weight of all them failed dreams in his eyes. If you cant smell the gasoline on his clothes. If you cant feel the loneliness eating at him like rust on an old chain.

The morning came dark and cold across the Ohio plains and with it the news of violence that plagues all men. On the screen they showed a man's face, hollow-eyed and vengeful, one Shad Hostettler who had taken blade to wife in Ashley. The newsmen spoke little of it, their words sparse as winter wheat, moving on like carrion birds to fresh killing grounds.

They told of a boy shot down in Sharon Woods, Travis Buyers by name, eighteen years on this earth before the bullets found him. The SWAT men moved through the streets like black-clad prophets but found nothing. The boy was black and the news passed over him quick as a shadow, the way it always does with such folk, while white victims draw the cameras like moths to flame, their stories told and retold until they echo through the empty spaces of the morning broadcasts.

A tale came then of a flying machine, a mercy ship pierced by lead, the small caliber round having punched through its metal skin like judgment from below. Five thousand dollars promised for the shooter's name, though such men rarely come forward in the light.

The weatherman spoke of rain and thunder, his words a incantation against the coming storm, the numbers of degrees meaningless in the face of what nature would bring.

They showed footage of a robbery, dwelling overlong on the darkness of the perpetrator's skin as if evil wore only one shade. Six foot tall they said he was, wearing death's own hood, moving through the UDF store like a specter of want.

Last came the story of Rodriguez, a Mexican who'd moved plants north for profit until the law caught him. Three hundred months they gave him, not twenty-five years, as if counting it slow made the time more real. His heritage they mentioned like it was a crime itself, though drugs know nothing of borders or blood.

They call it an ETF and it moves like some spectral thing through the markets tracking indices and commodities and baskets of assets that men have fashioned from numbers and dreams. It trades like stock but carries within it multitudes. Like some dark promise it offers what mutual funds cannot - the ability to sell short and buy on margin and purchase but a single share should that be all you possess.

The benefits lay there like bleached bones in the financial desert, stark and undeniable. Lower expense ratios than any mutual fund could claim. Yet darkness lurks at the edges for there are commissions to be paid, blood money for every trade like some ancient toll to cross the river of commerce.

They come in endless varieties these ETFs, each one different from the last but all bound by the same rules, the same principles that govern their existence. A man might question whether the benefits they tout - diversification chief among them - are real or merely mirages shimmering in the heat of market speculation.

We set our sights on one called IHF, to parse its essence against the ten largest holdings within it. To determine if owning the one could match owning the many, or if some better configuration might exist, like finding a new path through old territory.

The task demanded focus. To include every holding would be to lose oneself in a maze of numbers. So we took the top ten, accounting for 63.58 percent of the whole, like taking the measure of a man by his strongest features.

The calculations stretched before us like a map of some ancient territory, each figure a landmark in understanding how these ten stocks stood in for the whole of IHF. We normalized their percentages to 100, as if adjusting a compass to true north, and measured their contributions to Beta and Return as if weighing gold on scales.

The numbers spoke clear as desert stars - the return of the ten exceeded the ETF by 6.11 percent, a difference of 16 percent in total. The Beta ran lower by .12, like tracking softer footprints in the sand. Yet questions remained about whether these differences carried true statistical weight, or were merely phantoms in the financial wilderness.

The numbers fell hard that third month, like winter itself had reached in and torn the heart from our endeavor. Figure 17 told the tale plain enough. The New England cold come down like judgment, driving the bicycles to their hooks and the walkers to their cars, but that wasnt all of it. Not by half. December brought its own demons - papers to grade and tests to mark and the whole machinery of education grinding toward semester's end. The log books lay forgotten like dead leaves.

The holiday season stretched out before them all like some dark road with no end in sight. Students scattered like quail to their homes, faculty too, the campus standing empty and dead beneath the winter sky. When they returned in January the cold had settled deep in the bones of the earth and February showed no mercy neither. You could say the project started with fire in its belly but fire needs feeding and we had let it die down to embers. We conjured up what we called the Carpool Challenge Week in March, like some carnival medicine show come to town, and it worked after a fashion. The numbers rose again but the truth of it was we were fighting more than just the seasons and the academic calendar. We were fighting time itself and time always wins.

The deeper truth lay in the American soul itself. The car is freedom and freedom runs in the blood like whiskey. We tried to tempt them away with prizes. Gift cards for coffee and food, massages, books. But a man or woman behind the wheel of their own automobile is like God himself deciding when and where to go and that's a hard thing to trade for a free lunch. Later we wondered if bigger prizes might have turned the tide. A bicycle maybe. Or one of them hybrid cars with their silent engines and their promise of virtue. If we had played it different, saved the big prizes for when the winter came down and the spirit flagged, maybe the numbers would have told a different story. But maybes are like prayers - sometimes they get answered and sometimes they just drift away on the wind.

I sat there in the dim light watching them old Edison reels spin, fifteen of them from the years 1895 to 1901, all of them trick films they called them. Magic made of light and shadow and lies. The illusions danced across the screen like specters from some forgotten carnival, each one bound by rules old as theatre itself.

They were prison films in their way, trapped in boxes of their own making. Set-bound and frontal like some ancient proscenium arch in a dead man's playhouse. The camera stood witness, unmoved and unmoving, bearing testament to the conjurer's craft through long shots and medium frames, each film a singular moment stretched thin across time's cruel axis.

Yet some of them, those that came with the turning of the century, they dared. They broke free of their chains, splitting themselves into multiple shots like some cinematic hydra.

The stage held them all, these phantoms. Interior sets built like coffins for the living, the camera fixed and staring like death itself. No following of figures here, no chase through depths of field. This was vaudeville's bastard child, born in the womb of magic shows and carnival tents. The players moved like marionettes on invisible strings, side to side, never daring to approach the glass eye that watched them. In Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel, made in 1900, they shuffled across the frame like condemned men, entering stage right, moving in their horizontal dance of the damned.

The proscenium arch was their master and their god. Long shots and medium shots were its prophets, but close-ups were heresy, forbidden fruit in this garden of illusions. Like theatre-goers of old, we watched from afar, never permitted to breach that sacred distance between performer and witness.

One shot, one film. That was the law of their world, binding these spectral performances to mere minutes of life. Stories were sparse things here, stripped down to base trickery - disappearances, transformations, the stuff of street corner magicians and carnival barkers. But even in these simple deceptions lay deeper truths. The Execution of Mary, Queen of Scots, birthed in 1895, hid its secrets in plain sight. Look close enough and you can see where they stitched together the lie, where Mary's head wasn't Mary's head at all, though to the innocent eye it all flows like water over stone, one continuous stream of terrible truth.

The Gothic Novel stands as both ancient and new, a paradox of time itself, like bones bleached white in the desert sun yet still holding the marrow of life within. Ian Watt called it what it was, this thing that breathed both old and fresh air, praised and damned in the same breath by those who would judge such things. They spoke of its emptiness while others saw in it something terrible and sublime, like Burke did, though perhaps he knew not what darkness truly dwelt there.

When Walpole birthed The Castle of Otranto into this world he did what no man had done before, taking the ancient romances and the modern ones too and binding them together with blood and ink and shadow. He reached back into the theater of old times, into the stone and mortar of medieval walls, into traditions that lay like dead things but weren't dead at all. The word gothic itself had wandered like a vagrant through time, marking peoples and places and ways of being until it came to rest here, in these pages, in these stories that some called crude and others called revelation.

The chivalry of old times runs through these tales like a dark river beneath the earth. In Otranto it flows strong and deep, carrying with it the ghosts of knights long dead, their honor and their steel both rusted but somehow still sharp. Walpole saw his world, saw the men in it who called themselves noble, and found them wanting. He looked back to times when honor meant something more than words spoken in parliamentary halls, when blood spilled meant something sacred.

And there was Frederic, written onto the page like a man carved from older stone. A prince who had known suffering, who had walked with death in foreign lands where infidels waited with sharp steel and sharper faith. The writers made him more than man, made him legend, excess piled upon excess until he stood like a mountain of chivalric virtue, terrible in his perfection.

They call it supply chain management and it moves like a river through the world. From raw earth to finished good, from order to delivery, all of it flowing through the hands of men who may never meet nor know each others names. Keith Oliver gave it that name in 1982 though the thing itself existed long before any man thought to name it. He wrote of planning and control and efficiency but these were just words for an older thing. A thing as old as trade itself.

Six pillars hold it up. Production. Supply. Inventory. Location. Transportation. Information. Each one a world unto itself, each one bearing the weight of commerce like ancient columns in some forgotten temple to trade.

Production stands first among them. Without it there is nothing. It begins with knowing what men want, though want itself is a strange and shifting thing. The market tells us, if we know how to listen. Like reading entrails or watching the flight of birds, men in offices parse numbers and charts seeking auguries of desire. Once known, these desires become orders. Orders become plans. Plans become schedules. Schedules become reality in factories chosen for their capacity to birth these wants into the world.

I saw this once at Walmart and again at Target. Every movement prescribed, every action written down in books thick as bibles. How to wear the uniform. How to unload the trucks. The whole dance choreographed down to the smallest step, because chaos costs money and time is the only thing you can't buy more of.

Then comes supply, the choices of what to make and what to buy. What to keep close and what to send away. Managers sit in rooms and decide which parts of the work belong to them and which belong to others. They call it outsourcing but really its just a way of making things move faster, like water finding the quickest path downhill. They call this velocity and chase it like men once chased gold, always seeking the perfect balance of quality and cost.

They came in the Victorian age these books and they were filled with things of the aristocracy and details heaped upon details until the words themselves groaned under their own weight. But there were two that walked a different path. Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights. Dark tales both of them carrying mystery like a shroud and bearing strangeness in their hearts that set them apart from their kin. This strangeness it gave life to their characters and showed the blackness in their souls and the reasons for what they done.

He walked in dreams Oliver did between Sikes and Crackit who quarreled like wolves over meat and their voices came to him through the darkness of his mind. Then gunfire split the night and screams rose up like birds scattered from a field and lights danced before him while unseen hands bore him away through the chaos. Through it all the pain stayed with him constant as hunger constant as death.

These dreams they came in both books like dark prophets bearing truth. In Oliver's tale they showed what lay inside him like a man gutted and laid bare showing all the hurt and knowing that filled him. When they shot him and he lived it again in chapter 28 he was powerless as a leaf in the wind. The dream showed how the control had gone out of him like blood from a wound. He could not even see who carried him away and the pain that first shocked him now just stayed with him quiet and terrible like a companion. You could see how the boy was broke down by then like Fagin wanted. Beat down so far he wouldnt even try to save his own life when the time came. The day it went and night came on and the silence stretched out forever while the hours ran like water through his fingers.

Years back I worked with the young ones after their schooling was done for the day. Small faces looking up from dogeared books and crumpled papers. Their struggles were many but reading and words were what I knew best. There was this boy. Adrian they called him. Third or fourth grade, memory fails. The letters on the page before him might as well have been hieroglyphs carved in ancient stone. Some sounds he knew true as sunrise, others escaped him like smoke in the wind. His English flowed pure as mountain water but his people came from south of the border, that much was certain.

We labored together in that fluorescent-lit room until the day his mother appeared. The other children had gone off somewhere, just a few stragglers remained when she walked in wearing worry like a shawl. No English passed her lips, just rapid-fire Spanish that I barely grasped with my meager learning. That's when the truth hit me like a hammer stroke: The boy could read well enough, just not in the tongue of his adopted land. Whether this knowledge served him after, I cannot say.

I tell this tale not for its own sake but to speak of the wall that stands between languages in our schools, particularly here in California where the border breathes like a living thing. Sometimes the barrier hides in plain sight. Even a child who speaks English pure as spring water might stumble reading it, like a man trying to cross a river on stones he cannot see. We all know this truth, but what's to be done? For Adrian the path was clear enough: teach him the strange shapes that make up English words. But for those who barely grasp our tongue, the answer splinters like light through crystal. No single solution will suffice. Two-language teaching, immersion, private instruction, special English classes - each alone stands weak as a sapling in strong wind. But together they might grow into something that holds.

The two-language way shows promise, not just for the Spanish-speaking children but for all. Studies tell us these children outpace their peers like wolves outrun sheep. Some fear this wastes what we have, but they're wrong as wrong can be. Make it the rule instead of the exception and watch them all flourish like desert flowers after rain. We don't need every teacher speaking two tongues - that's a fool's errand. But we can find helpers, guides who know both worlds, to bridge the gap between what is and what could be.

From youth we are told of something greater than ourselves. A vastness beyond knowing. Some find it in wooden pews and stained glass, others in ancient texts or deep within the hollows of their own hearts. Many take up the faiths of their fathers like old coats passed down, worn thin at the edges but familiar. Others cast off such inheritance entirely, prophets of their own small worlds where nothing exists beyond the reach of their understanding. We wander these paths like blind men feeling their way through darkness, seeking some light to lead us from shadow into day.

He said cardinal and nothing more. We set on the porch watching the rain beat against tin while smoke rose from our cigarettes like small ghosts in the wet air. Water rushed through the gutters and drowned the flowers that grew wild at the porch edge. His eyes fixed on some distant point where memory and rain met in the growing dark. The clothes hung from him now like empty flags, his hair thin as winter wheat. Neither of us spoke of what was coming. What words could stand against such truth. I moved closer and we watched the June rain fall in the twilight like tears from an indifferent god.

December took him five days after I turned twenty-two. The medicines they gave him bought time but not peace, extending his suffering like some cruel mathematical equation. I questioned what sort of god would author such torment. In the nighttime I spoke no prayers. If there was something out there listening it had turned from me long ago like a friend grown weary of my voice.

I could not watch the ending. Would not. The memory of his life meant more than witnessing its departure. I knew him better than the others, better than those who shared his blood, and knew he would not want his child to stand witness while death took its due. For three days I lay curled in darkness waiting for word.

None came.

He walked the fields of Caroline County like a man possessed by the soil itself, this Taylor, his mind ever fixed on the republic and what it might become. The earth spoke to him in ways that politics never could though he served in both worlds, the dust of legislation settling on his farmer's boots like so much chaff. His devotion to the land colored everything he touched, everything he thought, everything he feared might come to pass.

The republic stood naked before him, stripped of old world traditions that might have bound it like corpse wrappings. Here was virgin territory not just in soil but in governance and Taylor knew it. He saw how rights given by God or nature or whatever dark force ruled the universe were bound together like a hangman's knot, to fail together or hold fast as one. The government, he reasoned, must never touch these things.

In those days men spoke of natural states and Taylor knew what that meant. The strong would devour the weak and the clever would feast on both, same as it ever was. But civilization demanded better. Taylor held to his beliefs about good and evil like a man clutching a Bible in a thunderstorm, knowing that any government made by men must carry both seeds within it. Good principles protect what's yours, he said, they make the earth yield its bounty, they keep the moneylenders at bay. Self-interest drives all men but only becomes evil when it feeds upon others like a carrion crow.

The Constitution was his lodestone though he wanted it read pure and clean as spring water. No federal leviathan growing fat on taxes and power, nothing beyond what was writ plain on paper. But words alone were dangerous things, he knew, without the ghost of intention haunting their margins. For Taylor the Declaration was the true testament, the document that spoke of sovereign states standing apart yet together, like stalks of wheat in a field that bend together in the wind but keep their separate roots.

He stood there and looked down and the looking was a thing without meaning or purpose save that it was what he did. The mind worked at it like some machine grinding away at nothing, processing the scene before him without attachment or judgment or understanding. Thoughts came and went like dust devils in the desert, there and gone again before they could take hold.

Years back he'd bought him a book about drawing from the right side of the brain on account of some artist he knew told him to. Since he was no more than a boy he'd wanted to draw and this book laid it all out plain as day from what a pencil was to how the mind saw shapes in the world. It talked about framing things. How you could take the world and cut it down to size with invisible borders. How a kitchen full of things could become just a bowl of fruit floating in space if you knew how to look at it right.

Standing there now he couldnt frame nothing. The sight before him was too vast and terrible in its simple awfulness. Like them painters who went through their phases. Picasso with his blues and Monet with his gardens. If this was art then it was art of the basest kind. A masterwork in brown.

His fingers found the handle and his arm moved like it belonged to someone else. The water moved in its ancient circles, clear as crystal and just as cold. Little pieces broke away and vanished into that cold void but the main mass stayed put like some creature born to that porcelain bowl. He flushed again harder this time, desperate-like, but that brown testament to human waste just sat there mocking his efforts.

He stood there in his uniform, green tie cinched tight at his throat like a noose, holding that mop like it was some kind of talisman against what lay before him. Just another bathroom cleaner at the Rite Aid facing down what some nameless patron had left behind. After a spell he reached for the paper, wrapped his hand in it like them old mummies in Egypt till he couldn't see skin no more. Then slow and careful-like he reached down into them cold waters like reaching into the mouth of hell itself...

They die on the roads these children. Die in twisted metal and shattered glass while the night moves past like a dark river and carries their souls with it. The government men with their papers and statistics know why but knowing dont stop the dying. They say the brain aint ready. Say its too new and soft for such things as steel horses and velocity. Experience too is missing like some vital organ cut away leaving only an empty space where wisdom should dwell.

These young ones they drive together. Pack animals sharing metal coffins. The California men who study such things showed in their numbers how death follows youth like a dark companion. State men made laws. Papers that say when they can drive and who they can carry but laws are just words on paper and death pays no mind to such things.

Some say eighteen years aint enough. Zuckerman the head doctor says they seek the thrill like moths to flame caring nothing for the burning. Says we ought to wait till that fire dies down some. But we dont wait and they keep dying and soon there'll be more. Children of the boom times coming up behind ready to take their turn at the wheel.

The answer lies plain as bones in the desert. Keep them from the wheel till eighteen years have worked their tempering. Let the schools teach them still but keep them from the metal beasts that roam the highways. Let them learn slow and careful like.
